This inner conflict leads Huck to make a profound decision: rather than betray Jim, he resolves to help him escape slavery, even if it means going to "hell" as per his ingrained beliefs.

After making this decision, Huck sets out to execute his plan, locating a hidden spot in the river to stash his raft. He then heads into town, where he unexpectedly encounters the Duke, one of the conmen he and Jim had previously traveled with. The Duke questions Huck about the raft and Jim's whereabouts. Huck fabricates a story about losing Jim and the raft, creating a plausible cover for his real intentions of rescuing Jim.

The passage highlights Huck's moral growth, his loyalty to his friend Jim, and his rejection of the corrupt values of the society around him. It is a pivotal moment that underscores the themes of friendship, moral integrity, and the individual's struggle against societal norms.

原文:
DON'T you like getting presents? I do. Birthdays and Christmas are always enjoyable times. We love receiving surprise presents. I remember visiting a house in the country once, and a little boy and girl of the house came into my room when my luggage was being unpacked, and eyed everything being taken out of my bag and boxes with the greatest interest. At last they could keep silent no longer.
"And what have you brought us?" they asked.
I was filled with confusion, for I had brought them nothing. I had not known of their existence. Their expectations were disappointed.
Another little boy of my acquaintance came to lunch with me one day. His mother was with him, and I think had talked to him beforehand about being on his best behaviour. I had got a toy for him to amuse himself with, and he had a very good time after lunch playing with it.
When he was going away, I told him he could take it with him. "I'll make you a present of it," I said.
To my surprise, he put his hands behind his back, and said, "Oh, no, thank you."
"Don't you want it?" I asked.
He shook his head, though he eyed it lovingly.
"I assure you, your mother will like you to have it," I said.
But nothing would induce him to take it, and he went away without it.
I fancy he was trying to be extra good. He thought it was not good manners to take a present away.
"What a silly boy!" you say.
But we often act like that with God. And it is such a pity, for we lose so much by not stretching out our hands to take what He offers us.
We may have a present offered us, but if we won't put out our hands to take it, what is the good of it to us? And how ungrateful to the kind giver!
Sometimes people get unsuitable presents. I heard of a little girl who bought a tiny doll's tea-set, and gave it to her mother as a birthday present.
And a scholarly old bachelor uncle gave his little nephew on his seventh birthday a Latin book, "Virgil's Aeneid."
We can fancy that neither of these presents was suitable!
Now God knows exactly what we want, and He gives us everything suitable to our age and circumstances. But there is one gift that is wanted by everybody, big and small, rich and poor. Many of the gifts we get in this world, wear out, and come to an end; this one cannot come to an end. And it is the gift that God likes to give us.
Some presents cost a lot of money. This one cost Somebody His life to get, and that makes it the most valuable gift in the whole world.
In the time of slavery, there was an old negro woman who had a son whom she loved very dearly. She and he lived and worked on a sugar plantation in the West Indies, for they were both slaves. But at that time some of the slave owners would allow their slaves to purchase their freedom, and though it cost them a great deal of money, some freed themselves in this way. It was this old woman's one desire in life to work overtime, save her money, and free her son from bondage.
She did not tell him what she was doing but she worked when he was asleep—and never took any rest or holiday herself. The consequence was, she ruined her health, and after many years of this dreadfully hard laborious life, she broke down, and had to take to her bed. But by that time she had earned the money to buy the freedom of her son. She called him one night to her dying bed, and produced a canvas bag.
"Here," she said, "is money to set you free, my son. You will never be a slave any more. I have worked all my life to get it, and now I have got the money, I die in peace."
She died in her son's arms—and he felt that his freedom had cost his mother her life.
Now the gift that God offers to us all cost the Lord Jesus Christ His life, and it is only through Him—or because of Him that we can get it.
What is it?

"The Gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord."

Is not Eternal Life a tremendous gift to be offered to us? Yet we can all have it. Every one of us—great and small—rich and poor. And if we know we have it, death will not make us afraid. Our souls cannot die. Eternal life with our Saviour in Heaven. That Land of Happiness which is too glorious to be described. Who would not stretch out their hands for such a gift?
But it needs empty hands to take it. We must let everything else go, and we must take the Lord Jesus Christ for our own Saviour. It is only for His sake, and through Him, that God gives us this gift.
Take it from Him now. Thank Him with all your hearts for giving it to you, and serve Him and love Him for the rest of your lives. That is how you can show your gratitude for such a gift as this.
It is the biggest gift you could have offered to you.
生成:
The scent of pine wafted through the room, mingling with the sweet fragrance of cinnamon and clove from the candle flickering on the mantle. It was Christmas Eve, and the Johnson household was alive with the excited murmurs of children. Their eyes sparkled like the twinkling lights on the tree as they eagerly guessed what gifts might await them the next morning. There was pure anticipation in their voice as each child spun a tale of the magic about to unfold.

In the midst of this festive whirl, young Timothy stood at the edge of the room, clutching a small but carefully wrapped package in his hands. He had been taught that accepting gifts was a privilege, not a right. His parents often reminded him to behave politely and express gratitude no matter what he received. But tonight had brought an unexpected internal conflict.

Aunt Clara, who had just knelt to his level, extended her hands, offering him a plush, velvety toy horse. The horse’s mane, a cascade of soft, black threads, beckoned Timothy. His heart raced with yearning, but he glanced at his parents and remembered their lessons about humility and politeness.

“Thank you, Aunt Clara,” he said, his voice as somber as his seven-year-old self could manage. He folded his hands behind his back, refusing the toy in a gesture meant to show restraint.

Aunt Clara blinked, confused. “Are you sure you don’t want it, dear?”

His internal battle was fierce, but Timothy nodded, believing this refusal was nobler. Aunt Clara, masking her dismay, drew back, her smile dimmer but unwavering.

In another corner of the room, Grandpa James sat watching, an understanding glimmer in his wise, aged eyes. Later that night, as Timothy sat by the fire, Grandpa James settled beside him.

“Timothy, may I tell you a story?” said the old man, his voice kind and inviting.

Timothy nodded, his earlier decision still weighing on his young mind.

“There’s a lovely story woven in our faith,” Grandpa started, his eyes glinting. “Do you know that sometimes, we are like you, Timothy? We too, are offered gifts, not of plush toys, but of immense value.” He paused, watching Timothy's face brighten in curiosity. “These are the spiritual gifts, and the greatest of them all is God’s gift of eternal life through Jesus Christ.”

Timothy listened, his young mind struggling to grasp the depth but feeling the sincerity in his grandfather's voice.

“Imagine someone offering you the most wondrous present, but you, for whatever reason, decide not to accept it. You remember Aunt Clara’s toy, right?” Grandpa James lightly patted Timothy’s knee.

Timothy’s face flushed as he thought back to his refusal. “Yes, Grandpa.”

“Your Aunt Clara wanted to bring you happiness, but you said no out of perceived good manners. Similarly, God offers us His ultimate gift—eternal life—but sometimes we refuse it because we hold on too tightly to our earthly understandings, our own ways of earning love and respect.”

Timothy’s brows furrowed. “Why do we refuse God's gift, Grandpa?”

“Sometimes,” the old man said thoughtfully, “we believe we must earn it, or we feel unworthy. Or we simply don’t realize the value of what’s being offered, because our hands are too full of other things—just like your hands were behind your back.”

Timothy looked down at his hands, now empty and resting on his lap. “What should I do then?” he asked softly.

“Have empty hands,” Grandpa replied, his eyes gentle. “Be ready to receive what is given freely and with love. God’s gift is precious and is available to everyone. All He asks is that we come with empty hands, letting go of our burdens and pride, and accept His grace and love through Jesus.”

Timothy's heart began to comprehend, little by little. He took a deep breath and, in that moment, he understood the profound beauty in simplicity—emptiness, not as a lack, but as readiness for divine fullness.

Grandpa James continued, “When we accept this gift with gratitude, we find new purpose. Our lives become a canvas for God’s love and service. We live each day in the light of His grace.”

The room was quiet, save for the soft crackles of the fire. Timothy felt a peace that was almost tangible, wrapping around him like a warm blanket. He leaned against his grandfather, the weight on his small shoulders lifting.

“I think I understand, Grandpa,” he whispered, his voice barely audible in the serene room.

“You will, more and more as you grow, Timothy. Just remember, God's gift is there for you, always ready, whenever you are.”

That Christmas Eve, as he lay in bed, Timothy's thoughts drifted not to the presents he might receive the next morning, but to the gift that Grandpa James spoke of—the gift of eternal life through Jesus Christ. With a heart lightened by understanding, he drifted off to sleep, a soft prayer of thanks escaping his lips.

The lesson that night lingered, a gentle reminder that the greatest gifts require nothing but empty hands and a grateful heart.
summary: The passage discusses the joy and significance of receiving gifts, both material and spiritual. It begins with anecdotes about children eagerly expecting gifts and a boy refusing a toy due to perceived good manners. The author then transitions to a spiritual theme, comparing our reluctance to accept God's gifts to the boy's refusal. The central message is that God offers us the ultimate gift—eternal life through Jesus Christ—which is immensely valuable and available to everyone. To accept this gift, one must have "empty hands," signifying the need to let go of other attachments and embrace Jesus as their Savior. The passage concludes by urging readers to accept this gift with gratitude and live their lives in service and love for God.

DON'T you like getting presents? I do. Birthdays and Christmas are always enjoyable times. We love receiving surprise presents. I remember visiting a house in the country once, and a little boy and girl of the house came into my room when my luggage was being unpacked, and eyed everything being taken out of my bag and boxes with the greatest interest. At last they could keep silent no longer.
"And what have you brought us?" they asked.
I was filled with confusion, for I had brought them nothing. I had not known of their existence. Their expectations were disappointed.
Another little boy of my acquaintance came to lunch with me one day. His mother was with him, and I think had talked to him beforehand about being on his best behaviour. I had got a toy for him to amuse himself with, and he had a very good time after lunch playing with it.
When he was going away, I told him he could take it with him. "I'll make you a present of it," I said.
To my surprise, he put his hands behind his back, and said, "Oh, no, thank you."
"Don't you want it?" I asked.
He shook his head, though he eyed it lovingly.
"I assure you, your mother will like you to have it," I said.
But nothing would induce him to take it, and he went away without it.
I fancy he was trying to be extra good. He thought it was not good manners to take a present away.
"What a silly boy!" you say.
But we often act like that with God. And it is such a pity, for we lose so much by not stretching out our hands to take what He offers us.
We may have a present offered us, but if we won't put out our hands to take it, what is the good of it to us? And how ungrateful to the kind giver!

But at that time some of the slave owners would allow their slaves to purchase their freedom, and though it cost them a great deal of money, some freed themselves in this way. But it needs empty hands to take it. We must let everything else go, and we must take the Lord Jesus Christ for our own Saviour. It is only for His sake, and through Him, that God gives us this gift.
Take it from Him now. Thank Him with all your hearts for giving it to you, and serve Him and love Him for the rest of your lives. That is how you can show your gratitude for such a gift as this.
It is the biggest gift you could have offered to you.

原文:
In the year 1653 there come sad news to Ellswether. My Lord Brandon, heading a rising for the young king in the North, was taken and beheaded; and my lady his wife, who had wearied herself in vain to obtain his pardon, died after giving birth to a daughter. Their son and heir had died in his infancy, and the barony must needs descend to a distant cousin of my lord’s, that was a boon companion of the king in France and Flanders. My lord’s estates and property was all confiscated, and for the poor babe was nothing left, save that she might have my lady’s gowns and suchlike. My lady had committed her babe to the charge of the gentlewoman that bare her company, desiring that she should be brought to Ellswether, and bred up by my mother. Wherefore this gentlewoman, Mrs Sophronia Skipwith by name, took with her the babe, together with my lady’s gowns and jewels, and the great portraits of her and my lord which he had had painted for her on their wedding, and divers tomes of French and English romances, and started on her journey. Coming to Ellswether, she found there sore lamentation, for that my dear mother had departed this life two days before. And Sir Harry, my father, finding himself with my Lady Brandon’s babe to keep, and discerning Mrs Skipwith to be a gentlewoman of most discreet conversation and a sobriety suiting her years (which were thirty-five at the least, and rather over than under), did offer her to remain as governess to the babe, the rather as the aforesaid Mrs Skipwith was an orphan and a distant kinswoman of my lady’s. Now if you look to hear that Mrs Skipwith made use of Sir Harry’s kindness to creep into his good graces, and thus marry him thereafter, you shall be disappointed, for she behaved herself throughout her life with a rare discreetness and wisdom, and hath left behind her a memory full of praise.
My good father, then, adopted for his own the little Mrs Dorothy Brandon (whose kinsman, even after the happy Restoration of his majesty King Charles II., when he gat back his lands, never troubled himself to inquire after her, lest for very shame he must settle on her a portion out of the estates of my lord her father), my father, I say, adopted her, intending in due time to marry her to me his son, and we grew up together as brother and sister, but in that prospect. Now at the Restoration, as I have said, there was many received back their confiscated lands, but my father, who (with his brothers) had sold and mortgaged all for the king’s service, gat nothing, since he had done it all willingly. There remained to us, then, only the manor of Ellswether itself, whereon was a heavy mortgage, that was fallen into the hands of Mr Sternhold, the attorney that my grandfather had been wont to employ. And again, if you look to hear in this place that Mr Sternhold proved himself a cruel or an unrighteous creditor, you will again receive a disappointment, for sure there was never no man that served better either the father or the absent son. But if this great burden of the mortgage was to be removed, it was needful for me to make my fortune, and this in no unspeedy way. And if you shall be surprised that my father allowed me, his only son, to undertake such a distant and dangerous manner of life as that I have followed, I would have you remember that Sir Harry, as was but natural in a gentleman of his family and breeding, cared more for the honour and name of the house than for him that might one day bear it, and that he sent me forth in quest of wealth for to redeem the estates, as any father in Rome might have sent forth his son in quest of warlike honour. After this explanation, which I trust shall resolve any matters that might otherwise seem to you obscure or contradictory, I will proceed to my tale.
Since I have spoke to you of my father’s poverty, you will readily perceive that he could not send me to any great school, nor was he likely, in the dark days that then shadowed this poor realm of ours, to commit me to the tuition of the schismatical minister that had usurped the room of the vicar of our parish, wherefore he was constrained to send me by the day to the grammar-school of Puckle Acton, which town lieth in the vicinage of Ellswether. Here, in common with the sons of many gentlemen of the country round, I gained a slight acquaintance with Greek and Latin, and (for which my life hath made me far more grateful) such a knowledge of the art of fence, of boxing and shooting, as hath often stood me in good stead. When I was not at the school, the time did often hang heavy for me, for the gentlemen’s sons of whom I have spoken durst not admit me to their company more than rarely, for fear of the suspicions of our tyrants, that were wont to scent a conjuration or conspiracy whensoever any number of Malignants (for so they called us) was met together. The company of the boys of the town I neither sought nor would my father have permitted me so to do, and I came thus, almost of necessity, to use and enjoy that of my little cousin Dorothy Brandon, in all my holidays and times of rest. ’Twas with her I learned from Mrs Skipwith to read French, and we loved to pore together over the pages of the ‘Grand Cyrus,’ that magazine of brave thoughts and witty conceits, of the ‘Cleopâtre’ and of the ‘Clélie.’ Of English books we had no great store, but in Sir Philip Sidney his ‘Arcadia’ and in Mr Lyly’s ‘Euphues’ we found a rare delight. Add to this, that my little cousin taught herself Latin in order to the reading it with me, and (her youth remembered) was no mean scholar in the Greek, and you shall see that we had no lack of fantastic and heroical reading for to divert ourselves withal.
生成: The year was 1653, and the sun had just set on the life of Lord Brandon, a staunch supporter of the young king in the North. His execution had been swift and, as many believed, unjust. His wife, Lady Brandon, soon followed him into death, succumbing tragically in childbirth. Little Dorothy, barely a few hours old, was left a helpless orphan, bereft and destitute in a cruel world that showed no mercy, neither for royalty nor their supporters. Loyally fulfilling Lady Brandon's last wish, Mrs. Sophronia Skipwith, a gentlewoman of delicate manners and immense compassion, took it upon herself to rescue the infant from the wreckage of her once noble family. She carried Dorothy through wind and storm to Ellswether, where she was received by my mother, a nurturing soul who agreed to rear the baby as her own. Alas, those gentle hands were not meant to cradle Dorothy for long. My mother passed away, leaving another gaping void in an already desolate household. My father, Sir Harry, a man of principle and proud lineage but inadequate means, found himself thrust into a position of reluctant guardianship. With a heart heavy with both sorrow and duty, he took the fragile infant into his care and appointed Mrs. Skipwith as her governess to ensure she would grow under the tender wing of nurture and education. During that period, England saw the tumultuous days leading to the restoration of King Charles II. Families across the land expected a reversion of fortunes with the return of confiscated properties. Yet, for Sir Harry, no such fortune arrived. The empty promises of wealth stayed true to their nature—empty and futile. The heavy mortgage on our manor towered above us like an ominous cloud threatening to drown us in an endless downpour of debt. Nevertheless, my father planned prudently to secure a future for our household. Dorothy, though not a blood relative, was enveloped into our lives and it was decided she would be my betrothed when I came of age. This arrangement, born out of necessity perhaps as much as kinship, was to cement her place among us and provide some semblance of stability amid our uncertain fate. Financial constraints weighed heavily upon our choices. Instead of the illustrious institutions that catered to the elite, my father sent me to the local grammar school. There, amidst worn books and overworked tutors, I received a modest education. My studies skimmed the surface of Greek and Latin, mere glimpses into the vast oceans of the ancient world. Practical skills, however, emerged as an unexpected boon in these unpretentious surroundings. Fencing, boxing, and shooting became my unlettered companions, training my body as much as my intellect. Dorothy and I became inseparable as we traversed the rugged paths of our youth together. Our favorite hours were those spent in the library, a sanctuary brimming with the wisdom of ages. We delved into French and English romances, tales of gallant knights and their fair maidens, immersing ourselves in worlds spun from the delicate threads of imagination. Each story enriched our spirits, broadened our minds, and cemented the quiet bond we shared. Many an afternoon slipped through our fingers, punctuated by rapturous readings and fervent discussions. In those quiet hours, words, once barred behind foreign scripts, unfolded before us like a blossoming tapestry. We deciphered love, loyalty, valor, and the difficult moral choices faced by heroes and heroines, recognizing their resonances within our own modest lives. Despite our financial struggles, our home was a haven of emotional wealth. Mrs. Sophronia Skipwith, though a governess on paper, became an integral part of our fragmented family. Her patience knew no bounds, and her wisdom stretched beyond the explicit teachings of books. She taught Dorothy and me that true nobility resided not in titles and lands but in the richness of one's character and the strength to persevere. Sir Harry, my father, though weighed down by the burdens of his house and a fortune that had long forsaken him, retained the honor and dignity inherited from generations of our lineage. He reminded us of our duty, not to the fading grandeur of sovereignty but to the personal compass we carried. King Charles II's restoration did little to alleviate our poverty. The world around us continued its turbulent spin of allegiance and betrayal. Yet, within the confined walls of our manor, a sanctuary endured, shaped by the loyalty that Sir Harry kept alive, the education Mrs. Sophronia Skipwith imparted, and the companionship that Dorothy and I cherished. Little did I know, these formative years were sculpting the core of my being, steeling me for the myriad adventures that lay ahead. Life, unpredictable and often harsh, had not yet extinguished our hope. As Dorothy and I stepped into the wider world, hand in hand, our shared past would become both our armor and our guiding star, illuminating the complex worlds we had yet to navigate.
summary:
The passage recounts a historical narrative set in 1653, detailing the events and aftermath of the execution of Lord Brandon, a supporter of the young king in the North. Following his execution and the death of his wife, who died in childbirth, their newborn daughter Dorothy was left destitute. Lady Brandon had entrusted Dorothy to Mrs. Sophronia Skipwith, a gentlewoman who brought the baby to Ellswether to be raised by the narrator's mother. However, the narrator's mother had recently died, prompting the narrator's father, Sir Harry, to take in Dorothy and appoint Mrs. Skipwith as her governess. Although the restoration of King Charles II returned many confiscated lands to their owners, Sir Harry received nothing and remained in poverty, necessitating efforts to remove a heavy mortgage on their manor.

The narrator, Sir Harry’s son, was brought up alongside Dorothy with the intention of eventually marrying her. Due to the family's financial constraints and the political turmoil of the time, he was sent to a local grammar school instead of a prestigious institution. Despite the limitations, he received a basic education in Greek and Latin and gained practical skills in fencing, boxing, and shooting. The narrator and Dorothy spent much time together, reading French and English romances, fostering a close bond and shared intellectual growth.

The passage sets the stage for the narrator's subsequent adventures and emphasizes the themes of loyalty, education, and the consequences of political allegiance.

原文:
In the year 1654 there come sad news to Ellswether. My Lord Brandon, heading a rising for the young king in the North, was taken and beheaded; and my lady his wife, who had wearied herself in vain to obtain his pardon, died after giving birth to a daughter. Their son and heir had died in his infancy, and the barony must needs descend to a distant cousin of my lord’s, that was a boon companion of the king in France and Flanders. My lord’s estates and property was all confiscated, and for the poor babe was nothing left, save that she might have my lady’s gowns and suchlike. My lady had committed her babe to the charge of the gentlewoman that bare her company, desiring that she should be brought to Ellswether, and bred up by my mother. Wherefore this gentlewoman, Mrs Sophronia Skipwith by name, took with her the babe, together with my lady’s gowns and jewels, and the great portraits of her and my lord which he had had painted for her on their wedding, and divers tomes of French and English romances, and started on her journey. Coming to Ellswether, she found there sore lamentation, for that my dear mother had departed this life two days before. And Sir Harry, my father, finding himself with my Lady Brandon’s babe to keep, and discerning Mrs Skipwith to be a gentlewoman of most discreet conversation and a sobriety suiting her years (which were thirty-five at the least, and rather over than under), did offer her to remain as governess to the babe, the rather as the aforesaid Mrs Skipwith was an orphan and a distant kinswoman of my lady’s. Now if you look to hear that Mrs Skipwith made use of Sir Harry’s kindness to creep into his good graces, and thus marry him thereafter, you shall be disappointed, for she behaved herself throughout her life with a rare discreetness and wisdom, and hath left behind her a memory full of praise.
My good father, then, adopted for his own the little Mrs Dorothy Brandon (whose kinsman, even after the happy Restoration of his majesty King Charles II., when he gat back his lands, never troubled himself to inquire after her, lest for very shame he must settle on her a portion out of the estates of my lord her father), my father, I say, adopted her, intending in due time to marry her to me his son, and we grew up together as brother and sister, but in that prospect. Now at the Restoration, as I have said, there was many received back their confiscated lands, but my father, who (with his brothers) had sold and mortgaged all for the king’s service, gat nothing, since he had done it all willingly. There remained to us, then, only the manor of Ellswether itself, whereon was a heavy mortgage, that was fallen into the hands of Mr Sternhold, the attorney that my grandfather had been wont to employ. And again, if you look to hear in this place that Mr Sternhold proved himself a cruel or an unrighteous creditor, you will again receive a disappointment, for sure there was never no man that served better either the father or the absent son. But if this great burden of the mortgage was to be removed, it was needful for me to make my fortune, and this in no unspeedy way. And if you shall be surprised that my father allowed me, his only son, to undertake such a distant and dangerous manner of life as that I have followed, I would have you remember that Sir Harry, as was but natural in a gentleman of his family and breeding, cared more for the honour and name of the house than for him that might one day bear it, and that he sent me forth in quest of wealth for to redeem the estates, as any father in Rome might have sent forth his son in quest of warlike honour. After this explanation, which I trust shall resolve any matters that might otherwise seem to you obscure or contradictory, I will proceed to my tale.
Since I have spoke to you of my father’s poverty, you will readily perceive that he could not send me to any great school, nor was he likely, in the dark days that then shadowed this poor realm of ours, to commit me to the tuition of the schismatical minister that had usurped the room of the vicar of our parish, wherefore he was constrained to send me by the day to the grammar-school of Puckle Acton, which town lieth in the vicinage of Ellswether. Here, in common with the sons of many gentlemen of the country round, I gained a slight acquaintance with Greek and Latin, and (for which my life hath made me far more grateful) such a knowledge of the art of fence, of boxing and shooting, as hath often stood me in good stead. When I was not at the school, the time did often hang heavy for me, for the gentlemen’s sons of whom I have spoken durst not admit me to their company more than rarely, for fear of the suspicions of our tyrants, that were wont to scent a conjuration or conspiracy whensoever any number of Malignants (for so they called us) was met together. The company of the boys of the town I neither sought nor would my father have permitted me so to do, and I came thus, almost of necessity, to use and enjoy that of my little cousin Dorothy Brandon, in all my holidays and times of rest. ’Twas with her I learned from Mrs Skipwith to read French, and we loved to pore together over the pages of the ‘Grand Cyrus,’ that magazine of brave thoughts and witty conceits, of the ‘Cleopâtre’ and of the ‘Clélie.’ Of English books we had no great store, but in Sir Philip Sidney his ‘Arcadia’ and in Mr Lyly’s ‘Euphues’ we found a rare delight. Add to this, that my little cousin taught herself Latin in order to the reading it with me, and (her youth remembered) was no mean scholar in the Greek, and you shall see that we had no lack of fantastic and heroical reading for to divert ourselves withal.
summary:
The passage recounts a historical narrative set in 1653, detailing the events and aftermath of the execution of Lord Brandon, a supporter of the young king in the North. Following his execution and the death of his wife, who died in childbirth, their newborn daughter Dorothy was left destitute. Lady Brandon had entrusted Dorothy to Mrs. Sophronia Skipwith, a gentlewoman who brought the baby to Ellswether to be raised by the narrator's mother. However, the narrator's mother had recently died, prompting the narrator's father, Sir Harry, to take in Dorothy and appoint Mrs. Skipwith as her governess. Although the restoration of King Charles II returned many confiscated lands to their owners, Sir Harry received nothing and remained in poverty, necessitating efforts to remove a heavy mortgage on their manor.

The narrator, Sir Harry’s son, was brought up alongside Dorothy with the intention of eventually marrying her. Due to the family's financial constraints and the political turmoil of the time, he was sent to a local grammar school instead of a prestigious institution. Despite the limitations, he received a basic education in Greek and Latin and gained practical skills in fencing, boxing, and shooting. The narrator and Dorothy spent much time together, reading French and English romances, fostering a close bond and shared intellectual growth.

The passage sets the stage for the narrator's subsequent adventures and emphasizes the themes of loyalty, education, and the consequences of political allegiance.

原文:
We could see Jacobsdal from the Weltufrede farm, a few buildings on the banks of a brook, and a neat little church, being all that this embryo town of the western Transvaal had then to show. After leaving it we turned north, then north-east towards Zeerust, the most important settlement in the[22] Marico district. On our way thither we passed one of the most productive farms in the neighbourhood; it belonged to a man named Bootha, and was traversed by the Malmani, which wound its way through a low rocky ridge to its junction with the Marico.
I made a preliminary visit by myself to the little town, but we did not actually move our quarters into Zeerust till next day. It covers a larger area than Jacobsdal, and any one devoted to natural science would find abundant material to interest him in its vicinity. We, however, only remained there a few hours, and started off for Linokana, outside which we encountered Mr. Jensen, who was bringing the mail-bag from the interior. The missionary received us with the utmost cordiality, and gave us an invitation, which I accepted most gratefully, to stay with him for a fortnight; the time that I spent with him was beneficial in more ways than one, as not only did it afford me an opportunity of thoroughly exploring the neighbourhood, but it permitted my companions to enjoy a rest which already they much required.
In 1875, the Baharutse in Linokana gathered in as much as 800 sacks of wheat, each containing 200 lbs., and every year a wider area of land is being brought under cultivation. Besides wheat, they grow maize, sorghum, melons, and tobacco, selling what they do not require for their own consumption in the markets of the Transvaal and the diamond-fields; it cannot be said, however, that their fields are as carefully kept as those of the Barolongs. A great deal of their land has been transferred to the Boer government, and they only retain the ownership of a few farms.

On the 9th I went to the sources of the Matebe and wandered about the surrounding hills, where mineral ores seem to abound. The following day I employed myself in drawing out a sketch-map of my route, and when I had completed it, I amused myself by an inspection of the plantations and gardens which surround the mission-station. I attended the chapel, where the service consisted of a hymn, the reading of a portion of one of the gospels, then another hymn, followed by a sermon; the impression made upon the congregation as they squatted on their low wooden stools being very marked, and the whole service in its very simplicity being to my mind as solemn as the most gorgeous ritual.
The native postman from Molopolole arrived late on the evening of the 15th, the journey having taken him three days; he only stayed one night, and started back again with the European mail that came through Zeerust from Klerksdorf. To my great surprise it brought me a kind letter from Dr. A. Petermann, the renowned geographer at Gotha.
An English major likewise arrived from the Banguaketse countries; he was in search of ore and was now on his way to Kolobeng and Molopolole; he gave us an interesting account of the reasons that had induced him and Captain Finlayson to explore the north-eastern Transvaal.
The Baharutse girls seem to be particularly fond of dancing, and we hardly ever failed of an evening to hear music and occasionally singing in various parts of the town.
One of the most picturesque spots in the whole[24] neighbourhood is in the valley of the Notuany, about three miles below its confluence with the Matebe; it is enclosed by rocky slopes broken here and there by rich glens and luxuriant woodlands that afford cover for countless birds, whilst in the sedge-thickets on the Matebe wild cats nearly as large as leopards lurk about for their prey.
生成:
The sun had barely risen as we set forth from Jacobsdal, a quaint town nestled by a tranquil brook. Our journey led us towards Zeerust in the sprawling Marico district. The road wound its way through picturesque landscapes dotted with bushveld and dramatic rock formations. The air was crisp, carrying with it the scent of wild grasses and distant mountains. We passed numerous velds and farmlands, one of which belonged to a man named Bootha. His land stood out with its abundance of crops swaying gently in the morning breeze, a testament to his agricultural prowess.

Zeerust appeared before us as a more considerable settlement, alive with activity and bustle. After a brief stay to replenish our supplies and take in the local atmosphere, we resumed our travels to Linokana. Upon arrival, the warmth of our welcome was palpable, delivered with genuine hospitality by Mr. Jensen, the missionary residing in the neat, whitewashed mission station.

For a fortnight, we made Linokana our home. It was an idyllic respite, granting my companions much-needed rest while giving me ample time to explore the fascinating surroundings. Mr. Jensen shared with me tales of the Baharutse community, who in 1875 achieved a bountiful harvest. Their efforts yielded not just wheat but a diverse array of crops, including maize, sorghum, melons, and tobacco. However, a shadow of melancholy persisted, as much of their fertile land had been requisitioned by the Boer government.

Throughout my stay, I immersed myself in the community. I trekked to Matebe's sources, where clear waters gurgled and danced over rocks, an inviting oasis in the arid terrain. With a steady hand and keen eye, I rendered a sketch-map of the area, capturing its intricate beauty and essential features.

The evenings bore witness to simple yet heartfelt religious services at the mission station. The gathered congregation, clad in their best attire, sang hymns that echoed in the cool evening air. The profound sense of faith and unity moved me deeply, transcending language and cultural barriers.

Amidst these serene moments, a letter arrived from Dr. A. Petermann, the renowned geographer. His words brimmed with scholarly fervor and detailed his latest discoveries in the uncharted corners of the continent. The letter served as a reminder of the broader world beyond our tranquil enclave.

One afternoon, I encountered an English major, a rugged yet amiable fellow. We shared tales over a campfire, his centered on his relentless search for ore deposits in these ancient lands. His stories spoke of both triumphs and disappointments, a testament to the relentless human spirit of exploration and ambition.

As dusk gave way to star-studded nights, the village awakened with the joyous laughter and rhythmic movements of Baharutse girls, who held evening dances under the open sky. Their dances were celebrations of life, tradition, and community, each step and turn resonating with ancestral echoes.

One of my favorite retreats was the Notuany valley, not far from Linokana. It was a place of breathtaking beauty, where verdant foliage met rugged cliffs, and the rich biodiversity painted a living canvas. The valley was a microcosm of South African splendor, with an eclectic mix of wildlife, from joyful birdsong to the rustle of small mammals in the underbrush.

My time in Linokana would be a chapter forever etched in my memories. Each day unfolded like a richly woven tapestry, capturing the essence of the land and its people. The experiences collected there became more than mere anecdotes; they were indelible imprints on the soul, whispering to me the timeless stories of Western Transvaal.
summary:
Certainly! Here's a summary of the main content of the passage:

The narrator describes their journey through various locations in the western Transvaal. They start from Jacobsdal, a small town by a brook, and move towards Zeerust, a more significant settlement in the Marico district, passing a productive farm owned by a man named Bootha. After a short stay in Zeerust, they travel to Linokana, where they are warmly received by a missionary, Mr. Jensen. The narrator stays for a fortnight, exploring the area and allowing their companions to rest.

In 1875, Linokana's Baharutse community harvested a substantial amount of wheat and cultivated other crops such as maize, sorghum, melons, and tobacco. Much of their land has been appropriated by the Boer government. The narrator explores the Matebe's sources, creates a sketch-map, and attends simple yet solemn religious services at the mission station.

Interactions include receiving a letter from geographer Dr. A. Petermann and meeting an English major who shares his ore-searching endeavors. Baharutse girls enjoy evening dances, while one of the most picturesque nearby spots is in the Notuany valley, known for its varied landscapes and wildlife.

原文:
Dr. Rawlings sighed a long sigh born of frustration and impatience and went wearily to the bookcase. Almost methodically he removed a large gold-titled volume of Freud's A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis and withdrew the bottle from its hiding place. The bottle was half filled with an amber fluid which jiggled pleasantly as he held it in an unsteady hand, observing with a practiced eye how gaily it sparkled in the late afternoon sunlight. Then from the cavity he also extracted a small whiskey glass.
He took these tools to his desk, poured himself a stiff one, downed it, flopped into his swivel chair and closed his eyes. Chicken farms, he thought. He felt the fiery liquid seep through him, warming his insides with its silent flame, bringing a pleasant glow of satisfaction to his mind.
He closed his eyes tighter and regarded the darkened world with a calmness that was somehow conducive to rational thought even in this irrational world. To thought and to sleep, he realized suddenly, as he found his head tilting.
He rose quickly, blinking off the effects of the liquor, and carefully returned the utensils to their proper niche behind the volume of Freud on the bookshelf. Good old Freud, he thought, always knew he'd come in handy one of these days. Then he returned to his desk to consult a small pad, and silently cursed the cruel fates that had given him patients tumbling upon one another in a ridiculously mad haste to reach the jumbled sanity of the normal world.
Why couldn't there have been a decent interval of time between them, so he could take a shower, or have a game of golf, or maybe even hang on a small one, or see a psychiatrist himself. Or maybe start that chicken farm he'd been talking about for the past two years.
He jabbed a button, said into the intercom, "Miss Austin, will you please send in the file on Mr. Charles T. Moore?"—and without waiting for an answer snapped the machine off.
Fifteen seconds later the door opened and Miss Austin walked in, a Manila folder in one lovely hand. As usual she was in an immaculately white uniform. White for purity? he wondered. It was a tight-fitting garment that clung to every curve as though hanging on for dear life, and on second thought he mentally erased the purity inscription on his mind's slate.
Miss Austin had a beautiful walk, and beautiful legs to walk on. He stared at them as she approached the desk. He always stared at them, fascinated, and she always knew he did, and she smiled that enticingly mad smile of hers that always made him want to give vent to an emotional catharsis.
God, he thought, how I'd love to psychoanalyze that woman! What a beautiful ego she must have. What a gorgeous id.
Carefully she deposited the folder on his desk, leaning forward strategically so her perfume could glide over him in intoxicating currents.
"Will that be all, Doctor Rawlings?" she asked in her honey-liquid tones.
"For now," he said, reaching for her hand and finding it. "But don't go away."
She smiled again, and gently freeing her hand, swept from the room. She looked even better from the back, if that were possible; after a few seconds deliberation he decided it wasn't possible. But it was women like Miss Austin that made him want a chicken farm, among other things. Miss Austin and a little tract of land far out in the country would be just perfect. In such a paradise he wouldn't even have to worry about the pecking order of hens. In fact, he might even get engrossed in raising things other than chickens.
Sighing again, he studied the folder before him, which did not take very long. The patient was still quite young even though he had already made a mark of sorts on the world. A theoretical mathematician, apparently. Probably thought himself a square circle on an adding machine. The psychiatrist browsed through the folder's contents again, then jabbed the buzzer.
"You can send Mr. Moore in now," he said and snapped the intercom off before Miss Austin could answer. The present moment was no time to be distracted.
Dr. Rawlings held his head in his hands and stared morosely at the desk. Then he picked up a pencil and began tapping it against an inkwell. An incongruous thought surely, pencil and inkwell—what would Freud say about that?
He decided in the same thought that he didn't give a particular damn what Freud thought about inkwells. There were times in fact when he didn't care what Freud thought about anything. There were times when all we wanted to think about was a small chicken farm, with maybe a gorgeous honey-blonde like Miss Austin to help sow a few seeds.
He looked out the window at the sky and the tops of buildings, and recalled with bitterness the patient who had claimed that he could fly, and who had tried to jump to the street forty floors below solely to prove it. It would have made a nasty splash, he thought. All the king's horses and all the king's men—Unless, of course, the patient really could fly....
He looked up, annoyed, and discovered that the door had not opened. Furiously, he jabbed the buzzer again. "Isn't Mr. Moore here yet?" he demanded, consulting his watch. "He was supposed to be here five minutes ago."
"He's here, Doctor," the receptionist's silk-and-satin tones came. "He's trying to get up enough courage to open the door."
"Oh," the psychiatrist said. He felt like adding something unprofessional, but he controlled himself. With an effort he shut off the intercom and just waited.
He looked up at the door and saw the knob turning slowly, ever so slowly. He watched its glistening facets turn in the dim natural lighting of the room, rotating as though in the slowest of slow motions.
He sighed and turned his attention to his desk top, where he discovered he had abstractedly pencilled on the blotter a four letter word not normally used in polite society. Hastily, annoyed with himself, he grabbed the pencil and used its erasing head to rub off the offending word.
When he looked up again, the door had opened the slightest crack. Damn, he thought, this job is going to drive me whacky yet. He recalled an episode of a few weeks earlier. He didn't want to, but the thought came just the same. Some of his patients had delusions so logical and systematized it was hard to prove to them that they were wrong. Sometimes it was hard to prove to yourself they were not right after all.
The woman from Mars, for example. She had actually believed that she was from the fourth planet, was really a Martian stranded here unaccountably. She had told a good straight story, but he had managed to convince her that she was not from Mars. He had persuaded her that she was an Earthling like everybody else, and that space travel of any sort was utterly impossible anyway.
He had been about to prove that there was probably no such planet as Mars when she'd decided not to come back. That was close to the time the meteorite landed a few miles away, the one that had never been found. After all, while not a usual occurrence, over-developed lungs and six fingers on each hand didn't mean—
The door edged open slightly, and an eye peered fearfully into the room. Then it swung wide, and the young man standing in the doorway let out a blastfurnace sigh that could be heard in surrounding offices.
"Come in, Mr. Moore," the psychiatrist said, "come in, close the door, sit down."
Mr. Moore did all these things with normal speed and in the proper order, but he did have a tendency to sit on the edge of his chair, as though he were sitting on a cliff and might topple over at any moment. The psychiatrist doodled on his pad impatiently.
"Well now, just what seems to be the trouble?"
Mr. Moore wet his lips. His face was white. He said, "I'm a mathematician. I work at the University."
"Oh," the other said, bringing to voice facts he'd read a few minutes before. "You're that Charles T. Moore, the one whose picture was in the paper a short time ago. Something about mathematics, I remember."
Moore nodded.
"Einstein, wasn't it?" the psychiatrist mused. "Something I don't understand, Einstein."
"It's not easy," Moore agreed. "That's what started my difficulty."
生成:
Dr. Frederick Rawlings leaned back in his leather-bound chair, a fortress of walnut and padding that had long ceased to provide comfort. The inherent sycophancy of the practice he once loved hadn't just crept up on him; it had engulfed him like ivy on a dilapidated manor, constricting more each year. He reached lazily for the bottom drawer of his heavy oak desk, pulling it open to reveal a hidden sanctuary—a bottle of amber whiskey, half empty. The gleaming liquid promised a moment of solace, a brief escape from the ceaseless parade of troubled individuals and their seemingly unsolvable issues. He poured a small measure into his coffee mug and took a swig, feeling the warmth flood through him, momentarily melting the stress forged into his bones.

His thoughts drifted back to a recurring escape plan—fleeing the confining walls of his psychiatry practice to start a chicken farm in some idyllic countryside. The thought had first amused him, then comforted him, and now, more frequently, tortured him. He imagined the simplicity of collecting eggs at dawn, the rhythmic clucking of hens replacing the incessant ticking of the clock on his wall.

And then there was Miss Austin. As his assistant, she was ineffably competent—sharp, punctual, and disarmingly attractive. It was a dichotomy that Rawlings found both compelling and inappropriate. Her elegant presence seemed to radiate through the frosted glass of his office door, where her silhouette could occasionally be seen organizing files or answering incessant phone calls. If she knew of his unprofessional attentions, she gave no indication, maintaining a demeanor as crisp as the white blouse she habitually wore.

A knock on his door, which Miss Austin must have orchestrated with her usual efficiency, pulled Rawlings from his reverie.

"Dr. Rawlings? Mr. Moore is here for his appointment," her voice was a melodic balm, yet pierced straight through his foggy thoughts. He cleared his throat, trying to shed the fatigue like a snake shedding its skin.

"Send him in, Miss Austin," he managed to reply, setting the whiskey bottle back in its clandestine drawer and steeling himself for another session.

Mr. Charles T. Moore entered the room tentatively, his movements stilted and laden with an unusual measure of hesitation. Here was a man ensnared not by the trivial trappings of daily life but by the infinitely complex realm of abstract mathematics. His eyes bore the hallmarks of sleepless nights and perpetual contemplation, and he clutched a worn leather briefcase as though it contained the secrets of the universe—which, in his mind, it very well might.

"Dr. Rawlings," Moore began, his voice a fragile whisper that seemed to quiver with each syllable, "I... I appreciate you seeing me on such short notice."

"Of course, Mr. Moore. Please, take a seat." Rawlings gestured to the armchair opposite his desk, trying to exude the calm professionalism that had earned him his reputation, now increasingly harder to muster.

Moore complied, lowering himself into the chair and placing his briefcase gingerly on the ground beside him. He glanced at the psychiatrist, his eyes darting nervously, searching for some signal of understanding or empathy. Rawlings gave an encouraging nod.

"What brings you here today?" Rawlings asked, pen poised over his notepad.

"It's my work... it all started with my work," Moore began, his voice gaining a firmer grip, though still haunted by a tremor of uncertainty. "I've been working on some equations related to Einstein's theories of relativity and complex mathematical models. At first, it was exhilarating. The challenges, the breakthroughs—it felt like I was on the brink of some great revelation."

Rawlings nodded, following the flow of Moore's narrative while keeping a clinical detachment. In his mind, however, he marveled at the sheer scope of the mental landscape this man navigated daily. He knew enough about Einstein's theories to respect their mind-wracking intricacies but wasn't familiar enough to grasp their full complexities.

"And then?" he prompted.

"And then," Moore continued, his voice dropping to a near whisper, "it became too much. It started with just a sense of unease, an occasional sleepless night. But then the anxiety grew, it... it metastasized, Doctor. Now it's like my mind is trapped in some endless loop of unsolvable problems, and I can't break free."

Moore's hands fidgeted, pulling at the cuffs of his sleeves, his disarrayed thoughts spilling into his gestures. Dr. Rawlings suppressed a sigh, recognizing the signs of deep psychological distress. Burnout was a common affliction among brilliant minds that wrestled day and night with the mysteries of the universe.

"Mr. Moore," Rawlings began slowly, choosing his words with care, "it's not uncommon for individuals in your field to experience this kind of cognitive overload. The human brain, while powerful, has its limits. Pushing beyond them consistently can lead to significant mental health challenges."

"But what can I do?" Moore's voice cracked, a wealth of desperation bleeding into his tone. "I can't just abandon my work. I wouldn't even know how to stop."

The sincerity in his plea struck a chord in Rawlings. This man was not unlike himself—trapped by the very passion that once drove him. Rawlings leaned back, the silent weight of his own professional weariness pressing upon him.

"We need to find a way for you to regain control, Mr. Moore. A balanced approach, one that allows you to continue your work but also safeguards your mental well-being," Rawlings said, though the advice felt as much for himself as for his patient. The irony wasn't lost on him.

As he outlined a potential treatment plan, with suggestions for cognitive-behavioral techniques and perhaps even a short-term sabbatical, Rawlings couldn't help but feel a kinship with Moore. Here were two men at the mercy of their vocations, both yearning for an escape they didn't dare fully grasp.

As Moore left the room, clutching a list of resources and a flicker of hope, Rawlings closed his eyes for a moment. The whiskey still burned a trail of warmth in his stomach, but it was the kindling of an idea, a yearning, that flared briefly to life. Perhaps it wasn't too late to make a change. Perhaps the chicken farm wasn't just a distant fantasy but a viable exit from a life that no longer served him.

With that thought, Rawlings stood up and opened his office door, signaling to Miss Austin that he was ready for the next patient. Her polite smile and diligent demeanor greeted him as always, but this time he looked at her with a different perspective. Maybe, just maybe, it was time to take a risk for something simpler, something fulfilling.

"Miss Austin," he began, his voice steady but laden with newfound resolve. "Could you clear my schedule for tomorrow? I need a day to think."

Her raised eyebrows were the only sign of surprise, but she nodded efficiently, already making the necessary arrangements. As Rawlings turned back to his office, he felt the stirrings of something he hadn't experienced in a long time—hope. And perhaps, the first inklings of a life less burdened by the relentless churn of other people's problems.

In the sanctuary of his office, he permitted himself a rare smile. Maybe, just maybe, there was a plot twist in his own story yet to come.

原文:
Dr. Rawlings sighed a long sigh born of frustration and impatience and went wearily to the bookcase. Almost methodically he removed a large gold-titled volume of Freud's A General Introduction to Psychoanalysis and withdrew the bottle from its hiding place. The bottle was half filled with an amber fluid which jiggled pleasantly as he held it in an unsteady hand, observing with a practiced eye how gaily it sparkled in the late afternoon sunlight. Then from the cavity he also extracted a small whiskey glass.
He took these tools to his desk, poured himself a stiff one, downed it, flopped into his swivel chair and closed his eyes. Chicken farms, he thought. He felt the fiery liquid seep through him, warming his insides with its silent flame, bringing a pleasant glow of satisfaction to his mind.
He closed his eyes tighter and regarded the darkened world with a calmness that was somehow conducive to rational thought even in this irrational world. To thought and to sleep, he realized suddenly, as he found his head tilting.
He rose quickly, blinking off the effects of the liquor, and carefully returned the utensils to their proper niche behind the volume of Freud on the bookshelf. Good old Freud, he thought, always knew he'd come in handy one of these days. 原文:
An elegant carriage stood in the middle of the road with a pair of spirited grey horses; there was no one in it, and the coachman had got off his box and stood by; the horses were being held by the bridle.... A mass of people had gathered round, the police standing in front. One of them held a lighted lantern which he was turning on something lying close to the wheels. Everyone was talking, shouting, exclaiming; the coachman seemed at a loss and kept repeating:
“What a misfortune! Good Lord, what a misfortune!”
Raskolnikov pushed his way in as far as he could, and succeeded at last in seeing the object of the commotion and interest. On the ground a man who had been run over lay apparently unconscious, and covered with blood; he was very badly dressed, but not like a workman. Blood was flowing from his head and face; his face was crushed, mutilated and disfigured. He was evidently badly injured.
“Merciful heaven!” wailed the coachman, “what more could I do? If I’d been driving fast or had not shouted to him, but I was going quietly, not in a hurry. Everyone could see I was going along just like everybody else. A drunken man can’t walk straight, we all know.... I saw him crossing the street, staggering and almost falling. I shouted again and a second and a third time, then I held the horses in, but he fell straight under their feet! Either he did it on purpose or he was very tipsy.... The horses are young and ready to take fright... they started, he screamed... that made them worse. That’s how it happened!”
“That’s just how it was,” a voice in the crowd confirmed.
“He shouted, that’s true, he shouted three times,” another voice declared.
“Three times it was, we all heard it,” shouted a third.
But the coachman was not very much distressed and frightened. It was evident that the carriage belonged to a rich and important person who was awaiting it somewhere; the police, of course, were in no little anxiety to avoid upsetting his arrangements. All they had to do was to take the injured man to the police station and the hospital. No one knew his name.
Meanwhile Raskolnikov had squeezed in and stooped closer over him. The lantern suddenly lighted up the unfortunate man’s face. He recognised him.
“I know him! I know him!” he shouted, pushing to the front. “It’s a government clerk retired from the service, Marmeladov. He lives close by in Kozel’s house.... Make haste for a doctor! I will pay, see?” He pulled money out of his pocket and showed it to the policeman. He was in violent agitation.
The police were glad that they had found out who the man was. Raskolnikov gave his own name and address, and, as earnestly as if it had been his father, he besought the police to carry the unconscious Marmeladov to his lodging at once.
“Just here, three houses away,” he said eagerly, “the house belongs to Kozel, a rich German. He was going home, no doubt drunk. I know him, he is a drunkard. He has a family there, a wife, children, he has one daughter.... It will take time to take him to the hospital, and there is sure to be a doctor in the house. I’ll pay, I’ll pay! At least he will be looked after at home... they will help him at once. But he’ll die before you get him to the hospital.” He managed to slip something unseen into the policeman’s hand. But the thing was straightforward and legitimate, and in any case help was closer here. They raised the injured man; people volunteered to help.
Kozel’s house was thirty yards away. Raskolnikov walked behind, carefully holding Marmeladov’s head and showing the way.
“This way, this way! We must take him upstairs head foremost. Turn round! I’ll pay, I’ll make it worth your while,” he muttered.
Katerina Ivanovna had just begun, as she always did at every free moment, walking to and fro in her little room from window to stove and back again, with her arms folded across her chest, talking to herself and coughing. Of late she had begun to talk more than ever to her eldest girl, Polenka, a child of ten, who, though there was much she did not understand, understood very well that her mother needed her, and so always watched her with her big clever eyes and strove her utmost to appear to understand. This time Polenka was undressing her little brother, who had been unwell all day and was going to bed. The boy was waiting for her to take off his shirt, which had to be washed at night. He was sitting straight and motionless on a chair, with a silent, serious face, with his legs stretched out straight before him—heels together and toes turned out.
He was listening to what his mother was saying to his sister, sitting perfectly still with pouting lips and wide-open eyes, just as all good little boys have to sit when they are undressed to go to bed. A little girl, still younger, dressed literally in rags, stood at the screen, waiting for her turn. The door on to the stairs was open to relieve them a little from the clouds of tobacco smoke which floated in from the other rooms and brought on long terrible fits of coughing in the poor, consumptive woman. Katerina Ivanovna seemed to have grown even thinner during that week and the hectic flush on her face was brighter than ever.
“You wouldn’t believe, you can’t imagine, Polenka,” she said, walking about the room, “what a happy luxurious life we had in my papa’s house and how this drunkard has brought me, and will bring you all, to ruin! Papa was a civil colonel and only a step from being a governor; so that everyone who came to see him said, ‘We look upon you, Ivan Mihailovitch, as our governor!’ When I... when...” she coughed violently, “oh, cursed life,” she cried, clearing her throat and pressing her hands to her breast, “when I... when at the last ball... at the marshal’s... Princess Bezzemelny saw me—who gave me the blessing when your father and I were married, Polenka—she asked at once ‘Isn’t that the pretty girl who danced the shawl dance at the breaking-up?’ (You must mend that tear, you must take your needle and darn it as I showed you, or to-morrow—cough, cough, cough—he will make the hole bigger,” she articulated with effort.) “Prince Schegolskoy, a kammerjunker, had just come from Petersburg then... he danced the mazurka with me and wanted to make me an offer next day; but I thanked him in flattering expressions and told him that my heart had long been another’s. That other was your father, Polya; papa was fearfully angry.... Is the water ready? Give me the shirt, and the stockings! Lida,” said she to the youngest one, “you must manage without your chemise to-night... and lay your stockings out with it... I’ll wash them together.... How is it that drunken vagabond doesn’t come in? He has worn his shirt till it looks like a dish-clout, he has torn it to rags! I’d do it all together, so as not to have to work two nights running! Oh, dear! (Cough, cough, cough, cough!) Again! What’s this?” she cried, noticing a crowd in the passage and the men, who were pushing into her room, carrying a burden. “What is it? What are they bringing? Mercy on us!”
生成:
The sun had just begun its descent, casting a golden hue over the bustling street when the chaos erupted. A carriage, drawn by a pair of spirited grey horses, barreled down the cobblestone road. The driver, clutching the reins with whitened knuckles, shouted futile warnings to the throng of pedestrians. The crowd parted just in time—most of them, anyway. Amid the utterly mundane cacophony of the market, a sudden gasp spread like wildfire. There, on the ground, lay a man, unconscious, having stumbled drunkenly into the path of the oncoming carriage. The horses reared in panic, their iron-shod hooves striking the figure covered in tattered clothes. A passerby screamed; another clutched their child close. It was a scene of utter pandemonium. 

The coachman, his face drawn and pale, gingerly dismounted. His eyes reflected a mixture of distress and resignation, as though he had encountered such tragic accidents too many times in his life. Standing before the unconscious body, he muttered anxiously to a gathering crowd, "I warned him; I did. Stumbled right in front of me like he was blind drunk. What was I supposed to do?"

From the back of the crowd, a young man surged forward, his eyes wide with recognition. Raskolnikov, with his threadbare coat flapping in the breeze, hauled himself to the injured man's side. His heart pounded as he knelt down. 

"Marmeladov!" he exclaimed, his voice cracking. The man on the ground, now surrounded by murmuring onlookers, was none other than Marmeladov, a pitiable retired government clerk who had long since fallen into ruin. Breathing heavily, Raskolnikov cursed under his breath. He could sense the life ebbing from the poor soul. 

"We must get him to his home," Raskolnikov said, looking up at the coachman with a steely gaze. "Not the hospital. He can receive immediate care at home. I’ll see to it."

"But, sir," the coachman began, his voice faltering, "he—"

"No time for debate!" Raskolnikov cut him off. "I will compensate you, and I will pay for a doctor. But we must hurry." 

The crowd buzzed with a mixture of curiosity and concern as Raskolnikov worked swiftly. Spotting a policeman, he called out, "Officer! Help us transport this man. Here"—he pressed a few bills into the man's hand—"make sure this is done quickly." The officer nodded, pocketing the bribe with a look of acknowledgment. 

With the help of the policeman and a few strong men from the crowd, Marmeladov was gently lifted onto a makeshift stretcher borne by two burly onlookers. Raskolnikov rushed ahead to Marmeladov's home, a place he knew too well—where desperation and hopelessness lived under one crumbling roof. 

The door creaked open to reveal a small, dank room that testified to years of neglect. Katerina Ivanovna, Marmeladov’s consumptive wife, paced incessantly, her frail body wracked with coughs that seemed to tear at her very soul. Her eyes, heavy with both worry and the feverish glow of sickness, widened in shock as Raskolnikov and the small procession entered, her husband’s battered body at the center. 

"Oh, dear God!" she cried, her voice rising in despair, "What has become of us?" 

The sight of her husband’s bloodied and unconscious form struck her like a bolt. She fell to her knees beside him, sobbing uncontrollably. For a moment, the severity of her own malady was forgotten; the cruel world had inflicted yet another blow. 

"Katerina Ivanovna," Raskolnikov started, his voice heavy with compassion, "he will be alright. We’ll get him the care he needs."

But she did not seem to hear him. Instead, she brushed her hand over Marmeladov's brow, fighting to suppress the surge of emotions welling up inside her. The room, drenched in the melancholy aura of their plight, echoed with Katerina Ivanovna’s lament. 

"This... this wretched life!" she sobbed. "Once, we had a home filled with laughter and prosperity. We had everything! And now..." She looked around the dilapidated room that bore witness to their downfall and choked back a fit of coughing. "It’s all because of him and his drinking! He may as well have killed us all!" 

Her children, sensing the gravity of the moment, gathered quietly in one corner, their faces etched with fear and confusion. Katerina Ivanovna, trying to regain her composure, instructed them in a hoarse whisper. 

"Dunya, fetch some water. Seryozha, bring the clean linens. We must care for your father as best as we can."

Raskolnikov looked on with a heavy heart, fully aware of the desperate straits this family was in. He saw Katerina Ivanovna’s hands trembling as she tried to clean the wounds marring Marmeladov’s body. Her every movement, although filled with a pitiful tenderness, betrayed the broken spirit of a woman who had tasted better days, only to have them cruelly snatched away. 

A knock on the door broke the anguished silence. The doctor, hastily summoned by the expedited efforts of Raskolnikov, entered. His gaze took in the dismal surroundings and the grievously injured man lying on the tattered couch. Without a word, he began his examination, his brow furrowing as he assessed the extent of Marmeladov’s injuries. 

The minutes dragged on, Franek—Marmeladov's eldest son—watched with anxious eyes as the doctor worked. Katerina Ivanovna struggled to maintain a semblance of calm, her hands clasping together in an unconscious prayer. 

"He...he will survive, won’t he, Doctor?" she asked, her voice barely more than a whisper, laced with fear and hope. The doctor paused, not meeting her eyes. 

"It’s too early to say," he replied somberly. "His injuries are severe, and he’s lost a lot of blood. But we’ll do what we can." 

As the doctor dressed the wounds and administered what little relief he could, Katerina Ivanovna continued to lament their downfall—her voice a plaintive wail against the silence of the room. 

"Oh, what a cruel jest life has played on us," she cried, her anguish resonating with everyone present. "Once, I had dreams of a better future; once, we had respect and dignity..." She paused, her eyes flickering to Marmeladov’s pale face, where traces of a tormented existence lingered. 

Raskolnikov, standing near the door, felt a pang of despair. He had played a part in many a desperate tale, but few had touched him as deeply as this. As he watched Katerina Ivanovna weep over her husband, he realized the depth of their suffering—a suffering that rippled out, entangling anyone who came close enough to care. 

In that moment, Raskolnikov was engulfed by a wave of empathy, an emotion that had become almost foreign to him. He felt a renewed determination to aid this broken family, even if it demanded sacrifices he was hesitant to make. In the face of such overpowering sorrow, any act of kindness seemed small. But it was in these small acts, he knew, that the essence of true humanity was found.
summary:
Certainly! This passage describes a dramatic scene involving a carriage accident in a bustling street. The carriage, drawn by spirited grey horses, has run over an unconscious, badly injured man lying on the ground. The coachman, distressed but not excessively so, explains that the victim stumbled drunkenly into the horses' path despite his warnings.

Raskolnikov, pushing through the crowd, recognizes the injured man as Marmeladov, a retired government clerk. Displaying urgency and compassion, Raskolnikov insists on taking Marmeladov to his nearby home rather than the hospital, believing he can receive immediate care there. He even offers to pay for a doctor and bribes a policeman to ensure swift action.

The scene shifts to Marmeladov's impoverished home, where his consumptive wife, Katerina Ivanovna, paces the room and laments their ruined lives, particularly due to Marmeladov's alcoholism. She nostalgically recalls her once-privileged life, instructs her children in household tasks, and endures severe fits of coughing. The arrival of the injured Marmeladov carried by the crowd shocks her, and the passage ends with her exclamation of distress.

In summary, the passage juxtaposes a chaotic accident scene with the backdrop of a family's dire situation, highlighting themes of poverty, desperation, and Raskolnikov's moment of empathy.
