原文:
The journey from Paris to Dresden at that time took five days and nights. On the German frontier, near Forbach, we met with stormy weather and snow, a greeting which seemed inhospitable after the spring we had already enjoyed in Paris. And, indeed, as we continued our journey through our native land once more, we found much to dishearten us, and I could not help thinking that the Frenchmen who on leaving Germany breathed more freely on reaching French soil, and unbuttoned their coats, as though passing from winter into summer, were not so very foolish after all, seeing that we, for our part, were now compelled to seek protection against this conspicuous change of temperature by being very careful to put on sufficient clothing. The unkindness of the elements became perfect torture when, later on, between Frankfort and Leipzig, we were swept into the stream of visitors to the Great Easter Fair.
The pressure on the mail-coaches was so great, that for two days and a night, amid ceaseless storm, snow and rain, we were continually changing from one wretched ‘substitute’ to another, thus turning our journey into an adventure of almost the same type as our former voyage at sea.
One solitary flash of brightness was afforded by our view of the Wartburg, which we passed during the only sunlit hour of this journey. The sight of this mountain fastness, which, from the Fulda side, is clearly visible for a long time, affected me deeply. A neighbouring ridge further on I at once christened the Horselberg, and as we drove through the valley, pictured to myself the scenery for the third act of my Tannhäuser. This scene remained so vividly in my mind, that long afterwards I was able to give Desplechin, the Parisian scene-painter, exact details when he was working out the scenery under my direction. If I had already been impressed by the significance of the fact that my first journey through the German Rhine district, so famous in legend, should have been made on my way home from Paris, it seemed an even more ominous coincidence that my first sight of Wartburg, which was so rich in historical and mythical associations, should come just at this moment. The view so warmed my heart against wind and weather, Jews and the Leipzig Fair, that in the end I arrived, on 12th April, 1842, safe and sound, with my poor, battered, half-frozen wife, in that selfsame city of Dresden which I had last seen on the occasion of my sad separation from my Minna, and my departure for my northern place of exile.
We put up at the ‘Stadt Gotha’ inn. The city, in which such momentous years of my childhood and boyhood had been spent, seemed cold and dead beneath the influences of the wild, gloomy weather. Indeed, everything there that could remind me of my youth seemed dead. No hospitable house received us. We found my wife’s parents living in cramped and dingy lodgings in very straitened circumstances, and were obliged at once to look about for a small abode for ourselves. This we found in the Topfergasse for twenty-one marks a month. After paying the necessary business visits in connection with Rienzi, and making arrangements for Minna during my brief absence, I set out on 15th April direct for Leipzig, where I saw my mother and family for the first time in six years.
During this period, which had been so eventful for my own life, my mother had undergone a great change in her domestic position through the death of Rosalie. She was living in a pleasant roomy flat near the Brockhaus family, where she was free from all those household cares to which, owing to her large family, she had devoted so many years of anxious thought. Her bustling energy, which had almost amounted to hardness, had entirely given place to a natural cheerfulness and interest in the family prosperity of her married daughters. For the blissful calm of this happy old age she was mainly indebted to the affectionate care of her son-in-law, Friedrich Brockhaus, to whom I expressed my heartfelt thanks for his goodness. She was exceedingly astonished and pleased to see me unexpectedly enter her room. Any bitterness that ever existed between us had utterly vanished, and her only complaint was that she could not put me up in her house, instead of my brother Julius, the unfortunate goldsmith, who had none of the qualities that could make him a suitable companion for her. She was full of hope for the success of my undertaking, and felt this confidence strengthened by the favourable prophecy which our dear Rosalie had made about me shortly before her sad death.
For the present, however, I only stayed a few days in Leipzig, as I had first to visit Berlin in order to make definite arrangements with Count Redern for the performance of the Fliegender Holländer. As I have already observed, I was here at once destined to learn that the Count was on the point of retiring from the directorship, and he accordingly referred me for all further decisions to the new director, Küstner, who had not yet arrived in Berlin. I now suddenly realised what this strange circumstance meant, and knew that, so far as the Berlin negotiations went, I might as well have remained in Paris. This impression was in the main confirmed by a visit to Meyerbeer, who, I found, regarded my coming to Berlin as over hasty. Nevertheless, he behaved in a kind and friendly manner, only regretting that he was just on the point of ‘going away,’ a state in which I always found him whenever I visited him again in Berlin.
Mendelssohn was also in the capital about this time, having been appointed one of the General Musical Directors to the King of Prussia. I also sought him out, having been previously introduced to him in Leipzig. He informed me that he did not believe his work would prosper in Berlin, and that he would rather go back to Leipzig. I made no inquiry about the fate of the score of my great symphony performed at Leipzig in earlier days, which I had more or less forced upon him so many years ago. On the other hand, he did not betray to me any signs of remembering that strange offering. In the midst of the lavish comforts of his home he struck me as cold, yet it was not so much that he repelled me as that I recoiled from him. I also paid a visit to Rellstab, to whom I had a letter of introduction from his trusty publisher, my brother-in-law Brockhaus. Here it was not so much smug ease that I encountered; I doubtless felt repulsed more by the fact that he showed no inclination whatever to interest himself in my affairs.
生成:
The year was 1842. Our journey from Paris to Dresden had been marked by an incessant sequence of trials and tribulations, testing our resolve and fortitude. As we crossed the border into Germany, the weather turned hostile almost immediately. The once clear skies darkened ominously, like a theater curtain descending before a tragic play. In no time, a relentless deluge engulfed our carriage, the cold rain seeping through every crevice, chilling us to the bone.

Traveling during the Great Easter Fair did little to alleviate our misery. The normally serene routes were now overcrowded with merchants and travelers, their carts loaded with wares and livestock. The cacophony of bustling humanity and the rhythmic clatter of horse hooves added to the unpredictability of our voyage. Sleep was fleeting, a distant memory of comfort as our bodies were tossed and jolted by the uneven road.

Yet, amid the unyielding hardship, a momentary respite was granted as we glimpsed the imposing silhouette of Wartburg Castle on a distant hill. Shrouded in mist, it stood as a beacon of resilience and timelessness. The sight of its regal turrets and ancient stone walls invigorated my weary spirit. Inspiration sparked within me, like a long-forgotten ember reignited. The trials of our journey seemed to diminish, replaced by a burgeoning excitement for future creations.

Our arrival in Dresden was met with an unceremonious reception. The city sprawled before us like an indifferent stranger, its streets cold and inhospitable. The grandeur I had anticipated was lost amid the labyrinth of stony façades and wintry air. No welcoming arms awaited us; instead, we found sanctuary in the modest quarters of a modest inn, far removed from the opulence one might expect of a city with such a storied past.

Having attended to some pressing business matters, I cast my gaze toward Leipzig, the city promised to reunite me with family. The anticipation of seeing my mother after a six-year absence swelled within my chest. The journey, still fraught with challenges, felt more bearable knowing that familial warmth awaited at its end.

Leipzig was a city of stark contrasts – bustling yet calm, modern yet steeped in tradition. Reuniting with my family was an emotional balm to my tired soul. My heart soared as I embraced my mother, who, much to my relief, was in far better spirits and living conditions than I had feared. My sister’s husband had seen to it that she wanted for nothing, his unwavering support ensuring her comfort and stability.

The familial paradise, however, was short-lived. Duty called, beckoning me toward Berlin with new goals in mind. I sought to arrange a performance for my work, "The Flying Dutchman," a prospect both exhilarating and daunting. News of Count Redern’s impending retirement sowed seeds of doubt about the trip’s efficacy. The uncertainty gnawed at me, foreboding a sense of wasted effort.

Berlin, a city teeming with intellectual vitality, held its own share of challenges. Navigating its complex social and professional landscapes felt akin to moving through an elaborate chessboard, each step requiring careful contemplation. My encounters with luminaries like Meyerbeer and Mendelssohn were illuminating yet disheartening. Meyerbeer, with his aloof demeanor, saw in me a competitor rather than a comrade, while Mendelssohn’s polite indifference masked an underlying skepticism about my work.

The mixed receptions were a bitter reminder of my precarious standing in the artistic circles I so wished to penetrate. Despite the frustrations and the sense of alienation that clung to me like a persistent shadow, there were moments of connection and understanding, brief yet significant. Every complimentary nod, every constructive critique, was a lifeline, guiding me through an ocean of doubt.

As I prepared to leave Berlin, my heart heavy with both hope and trepidation, I held fast to the belief that perseverance would see me through the trials ahead. For within the tempest of challenges lay the unyielding dream that had brought me this far. The road was still long, fraught with uncertainties, but it was the only road worth traveling.
summary:
This passage recounts a challenging journey from Paris to Dresden in 1842. The narrator describes encountering inhospitable weather upon crossing into Germany and experiencing severe discomfort and unpredictability while traveling amid the pressures of the Great Easter Fair. Despite the harsh conditions, the narrator finds solace in viewing the Wartburg castle, which sparks creative inspiration for future work.

Arriving in Dresden, the city appears cold and unwelcoming, heightening the narrator's sense of alienation. The couple, finding no hospitable welcome, stays in modest accommodations. After dealing with some business matters, the narrator continues to Leipzig, reuniting with family after a six-year absence. Here, they find the narrator's mother in improved living conditions, thanks to the support of her son-in-law.

The passage concludes with the narrator's trip to Berlin to arrange a performance of their work, "The Flying Dutchman." Complications arise as Count Redern is retiring, leading to doubts about the purpose of the trip. Encounters with notable figures like Meyerbeer and Mendelssohn reveal mixed receptions, underscoring the narrator’s ongoing challenges and sense of disconnection in professional and social spheres.

原文: SUPPOSING that Truth is a woman—what then? Is there not ground for suspecting that all philosophers, in so far as they have been dogmatists, have failed to understand women—that the terrible seriousness and clumsy importunity with which they have usually paid their addresses to Truth, have been unskilled and unseemly methods for winning a woman? Certainly she has never allowed herself to be won; and at present every kind of dogma stands with sad and discouraged mien—IF, indeed, it stands at all! For there are scoffers who maintain that it has fallen, that all dogma lies on the ground—nay more, that it is at its last gasp. But to speak seriously, there are good grounds for hoping that all dogmatizing in philosophy, whatever solemn, whatever conclusive and decided airs it has assumed, may have been only a noble puerilism and tyronism; and probably the time is at hand when it will be once and again understood WHAT has actually sufficed for the basis of such imposing and absolute philosophical edifices as the dogmatists have hitherto reared: perhaps some popular superstition of immemorial time (such as the soul-superstition, which, in the form of subject- and ego-superstition, has not yet ceased doing mischief): perhaps some play upon words, a deception on the part of grammar, or an audacious generalization of very restricted, very personal, very human—all-too-human facts. The philosophy of the dogmatists, it is to be hoped, was only a promise for thousands of years afterwards, as was astrology in still earlier times, in the service of which probably more labour, gold, acuteness, and patience have been spent than on any actual science hitherto: we owe to it, and to its "super-terrestrial" pretensions in Asia and Egypt, the grand style of architecture. It seems that in order to inscribe themselves upon the heart of humanity with everlasting claims, all great things have first to wander about the earth as enormous and awe-inspiring caricatures: dogmatic philosophy has been a caricature of this kind—for instance, the Vedanta doctrine in Asia, and Platonism in Europe. Let us not be ungrateful to it, although it must certainly be confessed that the worst, the most tiresome, and the most dangerous of errors hitherto has been a dogmatist error—namely, Plato's invention of Pure Spirit and the Good in Itself. But now when it has been surmounted, when Europe, rid of this nightmare, can again draw breath freely and at least enjoy a healthier—sleep, we, WHOSE DUTY IS WAKEFULNESS ITSELF, are the heirs of all the strength which the struggle against this error has fostered. It amounted to the very inversion of truth, and the denial of the PERSPECTIVE—the fundamental condition—of life, to speak of Spirit and the Good as Plato spoke of them; indeed one might ask, as a physician: "How did such a malady attack that finest product of antiquity, Plato? Had the wicked Socrates really corrupted him? Was Socrates after all a corrupter of youths, and deserved his hemlock?" But the struggle against Plato, or—to speak plainer, and for the "people"—the struggle against the ecclesiastical oppression of millenniums of Christianity (FOR CHRISTIANITY IS PLATONISM FOR THE "PEOPLE"), produced in Europe a magnificent tension of soul, such as had not existed anywhere previously; with such a tensely strained bow one can now aim at the furthest goals. As a matter of fact, the European feels this tension as a state of distress, and twice attempts have been made in grand style to unbend the bow: once by means of Jesuitism, and the second time by means of democratic enlightenment—which, with the aid of liberty of the press and newspaper-reading, might, in fact, bring it about that the spirit would not so easily find itself in "distress"! (The Germans invented gunpowder—all credit to them! but they again made things square—they invented printing.) But we, who are neither Jesuits, nor democrats, nor even sufficiently Germans, we GOOD EUROPEANS, and free, VERY free spirits—we have it still, all the distress of spirit and all the tension of its bow! And perhaps also the arrow, the duty, and, who knows? THE GOAL TO AIM AT....
生成:
In the grand hall of ideas where towering tomes and ancient scrolls whisper the musings of bygone eras, Truth stood as an enigmatic woman, elusive and unconquered by the myriad of figures who dared to seek her favor. Her ethereal visage had been the quarry of philosophers for millennia, yet none had succeeded in capturing her essence entirely. The philosophers, draped in cloaks of dogma and clinging to their rigid axioms, approached her with the seriousness of priests at a sacrificial altar, but their efforts, sincere though they were, often appeared as clumsy as children trying to grasp at shadows. For they had not understood that Truth, in her essence, was not a prize to be won by force or fervor but a delicate dance to be engaged with humility and grace.

Among these earnest scholars, the figure of Plato loomed large, his doctrines casting long shadows over the annals of Western thought. He had erected grand castles in the air, with concepts like Pure Spirit and the Good in Itself standing as monumental structures in the landscape of philosophy. Yet Nietzsche, with piercing insight, saw these edifices not as triumphs but as grave errors. Plato's ideas, he argued, were not pure discoveries of Truth but rather distortions that denied the multiplicity and perspectivism inherent to life itself. This denial was tantamount to a negation of existence, a philosophical austerity that could only lead to sterility.

Nietzsche's critique extended beyond Plato to what he saw as Platonism's most pervasive offspring: Christianity. To his eyes, Christian dogma was merely 'Platonism for the people,' a diluted and yet equally harmful embrace of absolute truths that shackled the human spirit. The struggle against such metaphysical chains had drawn the cultural bow of Europe taut, producing a tension that resonated through centuries. This tension, both an affliction and a propellant, had compelled the European mind to reach unprecedented heights of creativity, science, and introspection.

Attempts had been made to release this tension, to allow the bowstring to rest, and thereby achieve a kind of intellectual and spiritual peace. Jesuitism, with its methods and doctrines, sought to harmonize faith and reason, while the democratic enlightenment championed rationality and individual freedom. Yet, neither had fully succeeded. Jesuits imposed a new, albeit sophisticated, strain on the conscious self, and the enlightenment's drive towards egalitarianism and empiricism, though groundbreaking, failed to fully extinguish the haunting presence of dogmatic shadows.

In this ongoing saga, Nietzsche saw the emergence of what he called 'good Europeans'—those free spirits unburdened by the heavy ballast of old dogmas. These individuals, heirs to the accumulated wisdom and folly of their ancestors, stood poised on the precipice of a new intellectual horizon. They were tasked with aiming the cultural and spiritual bow towards uncharted territories, guided not by the prescriptive dogmas of the past but by a questing, transformative spirit.

The exact nature of these new goals remained cloaked in uncertainty, an enticing mystery akin to the elusive woman that was Truth herself. These 'good Europeans' understood that Truth was not a static entity but a dynamic process, an ongoing conversation rather than a monolithic proclamation. Engaging in this dialogue required a readiness to embrace multiplicity, to recognize that the perspectives of a thousand voices could offer a closer approximation of Truth than a single, unyielding doctrine.

And so, as the night of dogmatic philosophy waned, and the dawn of a more nuanced, perspectival approach began to break, these thinkers prepared themselves. They knew that their journey would be fraught with challenges, old misconceptions and new uncertainties, but they moved forward with the conviction that the pursuit of Truth, however elusive, was a worthy endeavor. With eyes keen and spirits undaunted, they aimed their arrows into the unknown, ready to follow wherever the intricate dance of Truth might lead them.
summary:
Certainly! The passage, likely from Friedrich Nietzsche, presents a critique of dogmatic philosophy and its failures, utilizing the metaphor of Truth as a woman who has never been won by philosophers. The text argues that traditional philosophical dogmas have been misguided, resulting in serious yet clumsy approaches to understanding truth. It posits that these dogmas may have been based on ancient superstitions, grammatical deceptions, or overly broad generalizations of limited human experience.

Nietzsche suggests that this dogmatism was necessary but misleading, comparing it to other historical grand pursuits such as astrology, which albeit flawed, contributed significantly to culture (like architecture). He particularly criticizes Plato’s concepts of Pure Spirit and the Good in Itself, labeling them as monumental errors that distorted truth by denying life's inherent perspective.

The passage also reflects on the struggle against Plato's ideas, equating it with a broader battle against Christian dogma, which Nietzsche sees as "Platonism for the people." This struggle has created a great tension within the European spirit, akin to a tightly drawn bow, leading to significant intellectual and cultural advancements. Attempts to relieve this tension have included Jesuitism and democratic enlightenment, but neither has fully succeeded.

Finally, Nietzsche identifies "good Europeans" and free spirits as the heirs to this intellectual tension and struggle, suggesting they hold the responsibility (and perhaps the means) to continue aiming towards new goals, even if the exact nature of those goals remains uncertain.

原文: SUPPOSING that Truth is a woman—what then? Is there not ground for suspecting that all philosophers, in so far as they have been dogmatists, have failed to understand women—that the terrible seriousness and clumsy importunity with which they have usually paid their addresses to Truth, have been unskilled and unseemly methods for winning a woman? Certainly she has never allowed herself to be won; and at present every kind of dogma stands with sad and discouraged mien—IF, indeed, it stands at all! For there are scoffers who maintain that it has fallen, that all dogma lies on the ground—nay more, that it is at its last gasp. But to speak seriously, there are good grounds for hoping that all dogmatizing in philosophy, whatever solemn, whatever conclusive and decided airs it has assumed, may have been only a noble puerilism and tyronism; and probably the time is at hand when it will be once and again understood WHAT has actually sufficed for the basis of such imposing and absolute philosophical edifices as the dogmatists have hitherto reared: perhaps some popular superstition of immemorial time (such as the soul-superstition, which, in the form of subject- and ego-superstition, has not yet ceased doing mischief): perhaps some play upon words, a deception on the part of grammar, or an audacious generalization of very restricted, very personal, very human—all-too-human facts. The philosophy of the dogmatists, it is to be hoped, was only a promise for thousands of years afterwards, as was astrology in still earlier times, in the service of which probably more labour, gold, acuteness, and patience have been spent than on any actual science hitherto: we owe to it, and to its "super-terrestrial" pretensions in Asia and Egypt, the grand style of architecture. It seems that in order to inscribe themselves upon the heart of humanity with everlasting claims, all great things have first to wander about the earth as enormous and awe-inspiring caricatures: dogmatic philosophy has been a caricature of this kind—for instance, the Vedanta doctrine in Asia, and Platonism in Europe. Let us not be ungrateful to it, although it must certainly be confessed that the worst, the most tiresome, and the most dangerous of errors hitherto has been a dogmatist error—namely, Plato's invention of Pure Spirit and the Good in Itself. But now when it has been surmounted, when Europe, rid of this nightmare, can again draw breath freely and at least enjoy a healthier—sleep, we, WHOSE DUTY IS WAKEFULNESS ITSELF, are the heirs of all the strength which the struggle against this error has fostered. It amounted to the very inversion of truth, and the denial of the PERSPECTIVE—the fundamental condition—of life, to speak of Spirit and the Good as Plato spoke of them; indeed one might ask, as a physician: "How did such a malady attack that finest product of antiquity, Plato? Had the wicked Socrates really corrupted him? Was Socrates after all a corrupter of youths, and deserved his hemlock?" But the struggle against Plato, or—to speak plainer, and for the "people"—the struggle against the ecclesiastical oppression of millenniums of Christianity (FOR CHRISTIANITY IS PLATONISM FOR THE "PEOPLE"), produced in Europe a magnificent tension of soul, such as had not existed anywhere previously; with such a tensely strained bow one can now aim at the furthest goals. As a matter of fact, the European feels this tension as a state of distress, and twice attempts have been made in grand style to unbend the bow: once by means of Jesuitism, and the second time by means of democratic enlightenment—which, with the aid of liberty of the press and newspaper-reading, might, in fact, bring it about that the spirit would not so easily find itself in "distress"! (The Germans invented gunpowder—all credit to them! but they again made things square—they invented printing.) But we, who are neither Jesuits, nor democrats, nor even sufficiently Germans, we GOOD EUROPEANS, and free, VERY free spirits—we have it still, all the distress of spirit and all the tension of its bow! And perhaps also the arrow, the duty, and, who knows? THE GOAL TO AIM AT....

原文:
He lifts his hands. Veils fall. O, flowers! Bells with bells with bells aquiring.
—Yes, indeed, the quaker librarian said. A most instructive discussion. Mr Mulligan, I’ll be bound, has his theory too of the play and of Shakespeare. All sides of life should be represented.
He smiled on all sides equally.
Buck Mulligan thought, puzzled:
—Shakespeare? he said. I seem to know the name.
A flying sunny smile rayed in his loose features.
—To be sure, he said, remembering brightly. The chap that writes like Synge.
Mr Best turned to him.
—Haines missed you, he said. Did you meet him? He’ll see you after at the D. B. C. He’s gone to Gill’s to buy Hyde’s Lovesongs of Connacht.
—I came through the museum, Buck Mulligan said. Was he here?
—The bard’s fellowcountrymen, John Eglinton answered, are rather tired perhaps of our brilliancies of theorising. I hear that an actress played Hamlet for the fourhundredandeighth time last night in Dublin. Vining held that the prince was a woman. Has no-one made him out to be an Irishman? Judge Barton, I believe, is searching for some clues. He swears (His Highness not His Lordship) by saint Patrick.
—The most brilliant of all is that story of Wilde’s, Mr Best said, lifting his brilliant notebook. That Portrait of Mr W. H. where he proves that the sonnets were written by a Willie Hughes, a man all hues.
—For Willie Hughes, is it not? the quaker librarian asked.
Or Hughie Wills? Mr William Himself. W. H.: who am I?
—I mean, for Willie Hughes, Mr Best said, amending his gloss easily. Of course it’s all paradox, don’t you know, Hughes and hews and hues, the colour, but it’s so typical the way he works it out. It’s the very essence of Wilde, don’t you know. The light touch.
His glance touched their faces lightly as he smiled, a blond ephebe. Tame essence of Wilde.
You’re darned witty. Three drams of usquebaugh you drank with Dan Deasy’s ducats.
How much did I spend? O, a few shillings.
For a plump of pressmen. Humour wet and dry.
Wit. You would give your five wits for youth’s proud livery he pranks in. Lineaments of gratified desire.
There be many mo. Take her for me. In pairing time. Jove, a cool ruttime send them. Yea, turtledove her.
Eve. Naked wheatbellied sin. A snake coils her, fang in’s kiss.
—Do you think it is only a paradox? the quaker librarian was asking. The mocker is never taken seriously when he is most serious.
They talked seriously of mocker’s seriousness.
Buck Mulligan’s again heavy face eyed Stephen awhile. Then, his head wagging, he came near, drew a folded telegram from his pocket. His mobile lips read, smiling with new delight.
—Telegram! he said. Wonderful inspiration! Telegram! A papal bull!
He sat on a corner of the unlit desk, reading aloud joyfully:
—The sentimentalist is he who would enjoy without incurring the immense debtorship for a thing done. Signed: Dedalus. Where did you launch it from? The kips? No. College Green. Have you drunk the four quid? The aunt is going to call on your unsubstantial father. Telegram! Malachi Mulligan, The Ship, lower Abbey street. O, you peerless mummer! O, you priestified Kinchite!
Joyfully he thrust message and envelope into a pocket but keened in a querulous brogue:
—It’s what I’m telling you, mister honey, it’s queer and sick we were, Haines and myself, the time himself brought it in. ’Twas murmur we did for a gallus potion would rouse a friar, I’m thinking, and he limp with leching. And we one hour and two hours and three hours in Connery’s sitting civil waiting for pints apiece.
He wailed:
—And we to be there, mavrone, and you to be unbeknownst sending us your conglomerations the way we to have our tongues out a yard long like the drouthy clerics do be fainting for a pussful.
Stephen laughed.
Quickly, warningfully Buck Mulligan bent down.
—The tramper Synge is looking for you, he said, to murder you. He heard you pissed on his halldoor in Glasthule. He’s out in pampooties to murder you.
—Me! Stephen exclaimed. That was your contribution to literature.
Buck Mulligan gleefully bent back, laughing to the dark eavesdropping ceiling.
—Murder you! he laughed.
Harsh gargoyle face that warred against me over our mess of hash of lights in rue Saint-André-des-Arts. In words of words for words, palabras. Oisin with Patrick. Faunman he met in Clamart woods, brandishing a winebottle. C’est vendredi saint! Murthering Irish. His image, wandering, he met. I mine. I met a fool i’the forest.
—Mr Lyster, an attendant said from the door ajar.
—... in which everyone can find his own. So Mr Justice Madden in his Diary of Master William Silence has found the hunting terms... Yes? What is it?
—There’s a gentleman here, sir, the attendant said, coming forward and offering a card. From the Freeman. He wants to see the files of the Kilkenny People for last year.
—Certainly, certainly, certainly. Is the gentleman?...
He took the eager card, glanced, not saw, laid down unglanced, looked, asked, creaked, asked:
—Is he?... O, there!
Brisk in a galliard he was off, out. In the daylit corridor he talked with voluble pains of zeal, in duty bound, most fair, most kind, most honest broadbrim.
—This gentleman? Freeman’s Journal? Kilkenny People? To be sure. Good day, sir. Kilkenny... We have certainly...
A patient silhouette waited, listening.
—All the leading provincial... Northern Whig, Cork Examiner, Enniscorthy Guardian, 1903... Will you please?... Evans, conduct this gentleman... If you just follow the atten... Or, please allow me... This way... Please, sir...
Voluble, dutiful, he led the way to all the provincial papers, a bowing dark figure following his hasty heels.
The door closed.
—The sheeny! Buck Mulligan cried.
He jumped up and snatched the card.
—What’s his name? Ikey Moses? Bloom.
He rattled on:
—Jehovah, collector of prepuces, is no more. I found him over in the museum where I went to hail the foamborn Aphrodite. The Greek mouth that has never been twisted in prayer. Every day we must do homage to her. Life of life, thy lips enkindle.
Suddenly he turned to Stephen:
—He knows you. He knows your old fellow. O, I fear me, he is Greeker than the Greeks. His pale Galilean eyes were upon her mesial groove. Venus Kallipyge. O, the thunder of those loins! The god pursuing the maiden hid.
—We want to hear more, John Eglinton decided with Mr Best’s approval. We begin to be interested in Mrs S. Till now we had thought of her, if at all, as a patient Griselda, a Penelope stayathome.
—Antisthenes, pupil of Gorgias, Stephen said, took the palm of beauty from Kyrios Menelaus’ brooddam, Argive Helen, the wooden mare of Troy in whom a score of heroes slept, and handed it to poor Penelope. Twenty years he lived in London and, during part of that time, he drew a salary equal to that of the lord chancellor of Ireland. His life was rich. His art, more than the art of feudalism as Walt Whitman called it, is the art of surfeit. Hot herringpies, green mugs of sack, honeysauces, sugar of roses, marchpane, gooseberried pigeons, ringocandies. Sir Walter Raleigh, when they arrested him, had half a million francs on his back including a pair of fancy stays. The gombeenwoman Eliza Tudor had underlinen enough to vie with her of Sheba. Twenty years he dallied there between conjugial love and its chaste delights and scortatory love and its foul pleasures. You know Manningham’s story of the burgher’s wife who bade Dick Burbage to her bed after she had seen him in Richard III and how Shakespeare, overhearing, without more ado about nothing, took the cow by the horns and, when Burbage came knocking at the gate, answered from the capon’s blankets: William the conqueror came before Richard III. And the gay lakin, mistress Fitton, mount and cry O, and his dainty birdsnies, lady Penelope Rich, a clean quality woman is suited for a player, and the punks of the bankside, a penny a time.
生成:
In the suffused golden light of the National Library of Ireland, a tapestry of voices wove intricate patterns of intellectual discourse. Buck Mulligan, his irrepressible energy palpable, leaned back in his chair, his voice buoyant with irony. "Well, well, and what says our distinguished Dedalus on this Hamlet business? Played by a woman, did you say? By Jove, what a fine jest!" 

Stephen Dedalus, seated opposite him, twirled a pencil thoughtfully between his fingers. His eyes, deep with contemplative shadows, met Mulligan's. "A fine jest or perhaps a deeper truth, Mulligan. Do not scoff at these postulations, for they may reveal the very essence of Shakespeare's mastery. And Wilde, ever the oracle of paradox, dipped his quill deep into such waters in 'The Portrait of Mr. W. H.'" 

"Ah, Wilde!" Mr. Best interjected with a chuckle. "The man who could hold a mirror to absurdity and find poetry therein. His speculations on Mr. W. H. are as much a dance of words as a pursuit of truth. A mirthful jeu d'esprit, wouldn’t you say?"

John Eglinton, scratching his bearded chin, murmured in agreement. "Wilde's play of wit, a frolicsome leap through the courts of Elizabethan intrigue and theatrical guile. And yet, beneath the merriment, a sincere quest for the heart of the sonnets, for Shakespeare's own soul." 

Buck Mulligan, eyes dancing with mischief, interjected with a flourish. "Gentlemen, let us not forget his contemporaries—Vining and Burbage! Actors who could carve the very air with their presence. Imagine the stage, a world entire, where Raleigh lights his pipe as Synge pens his delicate dramas. Our own Dublin a veritable echo of those august times!"

As laughter bubbled amongst the group, the soft thud of footsteps drew attention to an approaching figure. An attendant, his demeanor suitably solemn, approached Mr. Lyster with a discreet nod. "A visitor, sir, from the Freeman’s Journal. He requests access to the newspaper files." Lyster nodded, preparing to address the newcomer's need. 

Buck Mulligan, ever quick to seize an opportunity for levity, leaned closer, his voice a mock whisper. "Ah, the fearless press! No doubt an emissary well-versed in the art of stirring the populace. What say you, Eglinton? A tale of scandal or a search for truth?"

"A fine conjecture," Eglinton replied, eyes twinkling. "Perhaps our visitor seeks not the mundane but the profound—the hidden tapestries within these reams." Mulligan’s laughter melded with the ambient rustle of pages and muted footsteps, a symphony of scholarly pursuit flavored with jest. 

Lyster gestured the visitor into the room, the young man’s eyes wide with earnest intent. Mulligan couldn’t resist. "And what name graces our pages today? Tell us, sir, from whence do you hail?" The visitor, blushing under the scrutiny, murmured his credentials. 

Mulligan clapped him on the shoulder. "Welcome, good sir! A seeker amidst seekers. Come, join our merry band, if only for a moment. Share with us your tale or query—no doubt as worthy as any penned by Synge." 

Stephen, watching the interplay with an amused detachment, leaned back, his mind drifting to the ebb and flow of their prior discourse. The layers of Shakespeare's enigmatic life, Wilde’s clever contortions of truth and jest—all played within an intellectual theatre where each friend and foe wore masks of insight and fallacy. Moments like these, he mused, were the lifeblood of thought, where every jest hid a kernel of truth and every truth was cloaked in the garments of jest. 

Mr. Best continued, his tone scholarly. "To return to our dear Bard, the notion of a woman playing Hamlet need not be dismissed. Indeed, the roles of gender in Elizabethan theatre were fluid, a canvas for broader existential inquiries." 

"Aye," agreed Eglinton, his voice resonant with the weight of conviction. "And did not Sir Walter Raleigh himself challenge conventions in his quest for discovery? Think of Shakespeare in like pursuit, his quill mapping not just human hearts but the very horizons of identity." 

Mulligan rolled his eyes melodramatically, yet a smile played at his lips. "Must we forever dissect the great man? Let us instead concoct our own grand tales here at Connery’s!" He winked at Stephen. "And remember that night? The grand waiting game, the bottles lined like soldiers, the air thick with possibility?" 

Stephen's lips twitched. "A game, indeed. Each draught a passage, each jest a footnote in the marginalia of our lives." 

"A poet, always a poet," chuckled Lyster. "Your words have the ring of truth, though tinged with the mirth of a bygone revel." He turned to the visitor, nodding in deference. "And now, young man, to your purpose. What brings you to our hallowed hall?" 

The visitor, inspiration tempered by shyness, began his query, while the others returned to their leisurely pursuit of literary speculation, interspersed with nods and murmurs of recognition. Above them, the smell of old books mingled with the scent of ideas, fresh and ancient alike, hovering like ghosts in the hallowed air. 

The debate rekindled, and the room buzzed with renewed energy. References danced like motes of dust in sunlight—the intricate web of Synge's plays, Raleigh's exploits, and Wilde's paradoxical jests. Shakespeare's life, a multifaceted diamond, refracted laughter and earnest inquiry alike. Even the walls seemed to hum, resonating with the echoes of centuries-old discussions, the eternal dialogue between past and present. 

Mulligan’s voice cut through the ambient symphony. "Consider this, Stephen: the power of conjecture. Wilde's speculations, mere fantasies to some, breathe life into the staid realm of facts. What would Shakespeare be without the legends that surround him, the mythos that elevates him beyond the mortal coil?" 

Stephen’s smile was thin but genuine. "Agreed, Mulligan. Every legend, every jest, carries seeds of truth, waiting to unfurl in the fertile ground of inquiry. Facts are but the bones; myth, the flesh that gives them form." 

Mr. Best’s nod was almost imperceptible. "Indeed, the interplay of jest and earnest mirrors life itself—an interplay that Shakespeare captured like none other. And in this very library, we partake in that grand tradition, sifting through layers of history and myth, seeking understanding amidst the interplay of light and shadow." 

Lyster, satisfied that the visitor was well on his way to the back files, leaned back in his chair, eyes twinkling. "Well spoken, all. Let us continue to delve, to jest, to question. For in these very acts, we honor the spirit of inquiry that unites us, past and present."

Buck Mulligan raised an imaginary glass, his voice rich with feigned solemnity. "To the quest, then! To Shakespeare, to Wilde, to every soul who ever sought the profound within the absurd. Long may our debates resound within these walls, and far beyond!" 

As his words echoed, the library resumed its rhythm. Books whispered their secrets. Scholars pored over manuscripts, and amidst the grave pursuit of knowledge, the camaraderie of jest and earnest debate flourished, a testament to the enduring legacy of those who dared to think, to laugh, and to seek without end.
summary:
The passage is an excerpt from James Joyce's *Ulysses*, specifically from the “Scylla and Charybdis” episode, which takes place in the National Library of Ireland. It features an intellectual discussion among several characters, primarily focusing on Shakespeare and literary criticism.

Here's a summary of the main content:

1. **Literary Theories and Discussions**:
   - Characters, including Buck Mulligan, Mr. Best, and John Eglinton, engage in a debate about Shakespeare's works and biographical interpretations.
   - They reference various theories, including the idea that Hamlet was played by a woman and the speculative identity of Mr. W. H. from Shakespeare's sonnets.
   - Wilde's work "The Portrait of Mr. W. H." is also discussed, highlighting the humorous and paradoxical elements of Wilde's style.

2. **Character Interactions and Personal Exchanges**:
   - Buck Mulligan delivers a mock-telegraphic message to Stephen Dedalus, revealing their playful and teasing relationship.
   - Mulligan recounts humorous and exaggerated stories, involving drinking and waiting at Connery's.

3. **Introductions of Minor Characters and Actions**:
   - An attendant enters, informing Mr. Lyster of a visitor from the Freeman’s Journal seeking newspaper files.
   - Buck Mulligan mockingly identifies the visitor’s name and background, blending irreverence with sharp social commentary.

4. **Cultural and Intellectual References**:
   - References to Irish literature and theater, including mentions of actors like Vining and playwrights like Synge.
   - Historical anecdotes about famous literary and historical figures, such as Sir Walter Raleigh and Richard Burbage, are recounted, showcasing the range of cultural knowledge among the characters.

Overall, the passage blends lively dialogue with intricate literary analysis and character-driven humor, showcasing Joyce's complex narrative style.

Have you drunk the four quid? The aunt is going to call on your unsubstantial father. Telegram! Malachi Mulligan, The Ship, lower Abbey street. O, you peerless mummer! O, you priestified Kinchite!
Joyfully he thrust message and envelope into a pocket but keened in a querulous brogue:
—It’s what I’m telling you, mister honey, it’s queer and sick we were, Haines and myself, the time himself brought it in. ’Twas murmur we did for a gallus potion would rouse a friar, I’m thinking, and he limp with leching. And we one hour and two hours and three hours in Connery’s sitting civil waiting for pints apiece.
He wailed:
—And we to be there, mavrone, and you to be unbeknownst sending us your conglomerations the way we to have our tongues out a yard long like the drouthy clerics do be fainting for a pussful.
Stephen laughed.
Quickly, warningfully Buck Mulligan bent down.
—The tramper Synge is looking for you, he said, to murder you. He heard you pissed on his halldoor in Glasthule. He’s out in pampooties to murder you.
—Me! Stephen exclaimed. That was your contribution to literature.
Buck Mulligan gleefully bent back, laughing to the dark eavesdropping ceiling.
—Murder you! he laughed.
Harsh gargoyle face that warred against me over our mess of hash of lights in rue Saint-André-des-Arts. In words of words for words, palabras. Oisin with Patrick. Faunman he met in Clamart woods, brandishing a winebottle. C’est vendredi saint! Murthering Irish. His image, wandering, he met. I mine. I met a fool i’the forest.
—Mr Lyster, an attendant said from the door ajar.
—... in which everyone can find his own. So Mr Justice Madden in his Diary of Master William Silence has found the hunting terms... Yes? What is it?
—There’s a gentleman here, sir, the attendant said, coming forward and offering a card. From the Freeman. He wants to see the files of the Kilkenny People for last year.
—Certainly, certainly, certainly. Is the gentleman?...
He took the eager card, glanced, not saw, laid down unglanced, looked, asked, creaked, asked:
—Is he?... O, there!
Brisk in a galliard he was off, out. In the daylit corridor he talked with voluble pains of zeal, in duty bound, most fair, most kind, most honest broadbrim.
—This gentleman? Freeman’s Journal? Kilkenny People? To be sure. Good day, sir. Kilkenny... We have certainly...
A patient silhouette waited, listening.
—All the leading provincial... Northern Whig, Cork Examiner, Enniscorthy Guardian, 1904... Will you please?... Evans, conduct this gentleman... If you just follow the atten... Or, please allow me... This way... Please, sir...
Voluble, dutiful, he led the way to all the provincial papers, a bowing dark figure following his hasty heels.
The door closed.
—The sheeny! Buck Mulligan cried.
He jumped up and snatched the card.
—What’s his name? Ikey Moses? Bloom.
He rattled on:
—Jehovah, collector of prepuces, is no more. I found him over in the museum where I went to hail the foamborn Aphrodite. The Greek mouth that has never been twisted in prayer. Every day we must do homage to her. Life of life, thy lips enkindle.
Suddenly he turned to Stephen:
—He knows you. He knows your old fellow. O, I fear me, he is Greeker than the Greeks. His pale Galilean eyes were upon her mesial groove. Venus Kallipyge. O, the thunder of those loins! The god pursuing the maiden hid.
—We want to hear more, John Eglinton decided with Mr Best’s approval. We begin to be interested in Mrs S. Till now we had thought of her, if at all, as a patient Griselda, a Penelope stayathome.
—Antisthenes, pupil of Gorgias, Stephen said, took the palm of beauty from Kyrios Menelaus’ brooddam, Argive Helen, the wooden mare of Troy in whom a score of heroes slept, and handed it to poor Penelope. Twenty years he lived in London and, during part of that time, he drew a salary equal to that of the lord chancellor of Ireland. His life was rich. His art, more than the art of feudalism as Walt Whitman called it, is the art of surfeit. Hot herringpies, green mugs of sack, honeysauces, sugar of roses, marchpane, gooseberried pigeons, ringocandies. Sir Walter Raleigh, when they arrested him, had half a million francs on his back including a pair of fancy stays. The gombeenwoman Eliza Tudor had underlinen enough to vie with her of Sheba. Twenty years he dallied there between conjugial love and its chaste delights and scortatory love and its foul pleasures. You know Manningham’s story of the burgher’s wife who bade Dick Burbage to her bed after she had seen him in Richard III and how Shakespeare, overhearing, without more ado about nothing, took the cow by the horns and, when Burbage came knocking at the gate, answered from the capon’s blankets: William the conqueror came before Richard III. And the gay lakin, mistress Fitton, mount and cry O, and his dainty birdsnies, lady Penelope Rich, a clean quality woman is suited for a player, and the punks of the bankside, a penny a time.
summary:
The passage is an excerpt from James Joyce's *Ulysses*, specifically from the “Scylla and Charybdis” episode, which takes place in the National Library of Ireland. It features an intellectual discussion among several characters, primarily focusing on Shakespeare and literary criticism.

Here's a summary of the main content:

1. **Literary Theories and Discussions**:
   - Characters, including Buck Mulligan, Mr. Best, and John Eglinton, engage in a debate about Shakespeare's works and biographical interpretations.
   - They reference various theories, including the idea that Hamlet was played by a woman and the speculative identity of Mr. W. H. from Shakespeare's sonnets.
   - Wilde's work "The Portrait of Mr. W. H." is also discussed, highlighting the humorous and paradoxical elements of Wilde's style.

2. **Character Interactions and Personal Exchanges**:
   - Buck Mulligan delivers a mock-telegraphic message to Stephen Dedalus, revealing their playful and teasing relationship.
   - Mulligan recounts humorous and exaggerated stories, involving drinking and waiting at Connery's.

3. **Introductions of Minor Characters and Actions**:
   - An attendant enters, informing Mr. Lyster of a visitor from the Freeman’s Journal seeking newspaper files.
   - Buck Mulligan mockingly identifies the visitor’s name and background, blending irreverence with sharp social commentary.

4. **Cultural and Intellectual References**:
   - References to Irish literature and theater, including mentions of actors like Vining and playwrights like Synge.
   - Historical anecdotes about famous literary and historical figures, such as Sir Walter Raleigh and Richard Burbage, are recounted, showcasing the range of cultural knowledge among the characters.

Overall, the passage blends lively dialogue with intricate literary analysis and character-driven humor, showcasing Joyce's complex narrative style.

—Yes, indeed, the quaker librarian said. A most instructive discussion. Mr Mulligan, I’ll be bound, has his theory too of the play and of Shakespeare. All sides of life should be represented.
He smiled on all sides equally.
Buck Mulligan thought, puzzled:
—Shakespeare? he said. I seem to know the name.
A flying sunny smile rayed in his loose features.
—To be sure, he said, remembering brightly. The chap that writes like Synge.
Mr Best turned to him.
—Haines missed you, he said. Did you meet him? He’ll see you after at the D. B. C. He’s gone to Gill’s to buy Hyde’s Lovesongs of Connacht.
—I came through the museum, Buck Mulligan said. Was he here?
—The bard’s fellowcountrymen, John Eglinton answered, are rather tired perhaps of our brilliancies of theorising. I hear that an actress played Hamlet for the fourhundredandeighth time last night in Dublin. Vining held that the prince was a woman. Has no-one made him out to be an Irishman? Judge Barton, I believe, is searching for some clues. He swears (His Highness not His Lordship) by saint Patrick.
—The most brilliant of all is that story of Wilde’s, Mr Best said, lifting his brilliant notebook. That Portrait of Mr W. H. where he proves that the sonnets were written by a Willie Hughes, a man all hues.
—For Willie Hughes, is it not? the quaker librarian asked.
Or Hughie Wills? Mr William Himself. W. H.: who am I?
—I mean, for Willie Hughes, Mr Best said, amending his gloss easily. Of course it’s all paradox, don’t you know, Hughes and hews and hues, the colour, but it’s so typical the way he works it out. It’s the very essence of Wilde, don’t you know. The light touch.
His glance touched their faces lightly as he smiled, a blond ephebe. Tame essence of Wilde.
You’re darned witty. Three drams of usquebaugh you drank with Dan Deasy’s ducats.
How much did I spend? O, a few shillings.
For a plump of pressmen. Humour wet and dry.
Wit. You would give your five wits for youth’s proud livery he pranks in. Lineaments of gratified desire.
There be many mo. Take her for me. In pairing time. Jove, a cool ruttime send them. Yea, turtledove her.
Eve. Naked wheatbellied sin. A snake coils her, fang in’s kiss.
—Do you think it is only a paradox? the quaker librarian was asking. The mocker is never taken seriously when he is most serious.
They talked seriously of mocker’s seriousness.

原文:
For the main plot we have no direct source. It represents, however, Jonson’s typical method. It has been pointed out([53]) that the characteristic Jonsonian comedy always consists of two groups, the intriguers and the victims. In The Devil is an Ass the most purely comic motive of the play is furnished by a reversal of the usual relation subsisting between these two groups. Here the devil, who was wont to be looked upon as arch-intriguer, is constantly ‘fooled off and beaten’, and thus takes his position as the comic butt. Pug, in a sense, represents a satirical trend. Through him Jonson satirizes the outgrown supernaturalism which still clung to the skirts [xlii]of Jacobean realism, and at the same time paints in lively colors the vice of a society against which hell itself is powerless to contend. It is only, however, in a general way, where the devil stands for a principle, that Pug may be considered as in any degree satirical. In the particular incident he is always a purely comic figure, and furnishes the mirth which results from a sense of the incongruity between anticipation and accomplishment.
Fitzdottrel, on the other hand, is mainly satirical. Through him Jonson passes censure upon the city gallant, the attendant at the theatre, the victim of the prevalent superstitions, and even the pretended demoniac. His dupery, as in the case of his bargain with Wittipol, excites indignation rather than mirth, and his final discomfiture affords us almost a sense of poetic justice. This character stands in the position of chief victim.
In an intermediate position are Merecraft and Everill. They succeed in swindling Fitzdottrel and Lady Tailbush, but are in turn played upon by the chief intriguer, Wittipol, with his friend Manly. Jonson’s moral purpose is here plainly visible, especially in contrast to Plautus, with whom the youthful intriguer is also the stock figure. The motive of the young man’s trickery in the Latin comedy is usually unworthy and selfish. That of Wittipol, on the other hand, is wholly disinterested, since he is represented as having already philosophically accepted the rejection of his advances at the hands of Mrs. Fitzdottrel.
In construction the play suffers from overabundance of material. Instead of a single main line of action, which is given clear precedence, there is rather a succession of elaborated episodes, carefully connected and motivated, but not properly subordinated. The plot is coherent and intricate rather than unified. This is further aggravated by the fact that the chief objects of satire are imperfectly understood by readers of the present day.
Jonson observes unity of time, Pug coming to earth in the morning and returning at midnight. With the exception [xliii]of the first scene, which is indeterminate, and seems at one moment to be hell, and the next London, the action is confined to the City, but hovers between Lincoln’s Inn, Newgate, and the house of Lady Tailbush. Unity of action is of course broken by the interference of the devil-plot and the episodic nature of the satirical plot. The main lines of action may be discussed separately.
In the first act chief prominence is given to the intrigue between Wittipol and Mrs. Fitzdottrel. This interest is continued through the second act, but practically dropped after this point. In Act 4 we find that both lovers have recovered from their infatuation, and the intrigue ends by mutual consent.
The second act opens with the episode of Merecraft’s plot to gull Fitzdottrel. The project of the dukedom of Drownedland is given chief place, and attention is centred upon it both here and in the following scenes. Little use, however, is made of it in the motivation of action. This is left for another project, the office of the Master of Dependencies (quarrels) in the next act. This device is introduced in an incidental way, and we are not prepared for the important place which it takes in the development of the plot. Merecraft, goaded by Everill, hits upon it merely as a temporary makeshift to extort money from Fitzdottrel. The latter determines to make use of the office in prosecuting his quarrel with Wittipol. In preparation for the duel, and in accordance with the course of procedure laid down by Everill, he resolves to settle his estate. Merecraft and Everill endeavor to have the deed drawn in their own favor, but through the interference of Wittipol the whole estate is made over to Manly, who restores it to Mrs. Fitzdottrel. This project becomes then the real turning-point of the play.
The episode of Guilthead and Plutarchus in Act 3 is only slightly connected with the main plot. That of Wittipol’s disguise as a Spanish lady, touched upon in the first two acts, becomes the chief [xliv]interest of the fourth. It furnishes much comic material, and the characters of Lady Tailbush and Lady Eitherside offer the poet the opportunity for some of his cleverest touches in characterization and contrast.([54]) The scene, however, is introduced for incidental purposes, the satirization of foreign fashions and the follies of London society, and is overelaborated. The catalogue of cosmetics is an instance of Jonson’s intimate acquaintance with recondite knowledge standing in the way of his art.
Merecraft’s ‘after game’ in the fifth act is of the nature of an appendix. The play might well have ended with the frustration of his plan to get possession of the estate. This act is introduced chiefly for the sake of a satire upon pretended demoniacs and witch-finders. It also contains the conclusion of the devil-plot.
The Devil is an Ass will always remain valuable as a historical document, and as a record of Jonson’s own attitude towards the abuses of his times. In the treatment of Fitzdottrel and Merecraft among the chief persons, and of Plutarchus Guilthead among the lesser, this play belongs to Jonson’s character-drama.([55]) It does not, however, belong to the pure humor-comedy. Like The Alchemist, and in marked contrast to Every Man out of his Humor, interest is sought in plot development. In the scene between Lady Tailbush and Lady Eitherside, the play becomes a comedy of manners, and in its attack upon state abuses it is semi-political in nature. Both Gifford and Swinburne have observed the ethical treatment of the main motives.
With the exception of Prologue and Epilogue, the doggerel couplets spoken by Iniquity, Wittipol’s song (2. 6. 94), and some of the lines quoted by Fitzdottrel in the last scene, the play is written in blank verse throughout. Occasional lines of eight (2. 2. 122), nine (2. 1. 1), [xlv]twelve (1. 1. 33) or thirteen (1. 1. 113) syllables are introduced. Most of these could easily be normalized by a slight emendation or the slurring of a syllable in pronunciation. Many of the lines, however, are rough and difficult of scansion. Most of the dialogue is vigorous, though Wittipol’s language is sometimes affected and unnatural (cf. Act 1. Sc. 1). His speech, 1. 6. 111-148, is classical in tone, but fragmentary and not perfectly assimilated. The song already referred to possesses delicacy and some beauty of imagery, but lacks Jonson’s customary polish and smoothness.
As a work of art the play must rely chiefly upon the vigor of its satiric dialogue and the cleverness of its character sketches. It lacks the chief excellences of construction—unity of interest, subordination of detail, steady and uninterrupted development, and prompt conclusion.
生成:
In the bustling streets of London, the decrepit old theatre on Fleet Street buzzed with anticipation. Tonight, Ben Jonson's latest play, 'The Devil is an Ass,' was set to premiere. The fragrance of roasted chestnuts and the din of hawkers outside the theatre filled the air, adding to the chaotic charm of the city. Playgoers, from society's elite to its common folk, converged here, awaiting the curtain's rise with bated breath.

Inside, the stage was a carefully arranged mockery of 17th-century London life. Props of merchant stalls, narrow alleyways, and ornate drawing rooms spread across the wooden platform. Just as the play was about to commence, a hush fell over the audience, the lights dimmed, and the prologue began.

The story opened with Pug, a bumbling devil dispatched from Hell to wreak havoc on earth. Unlike the traditional omnipotent tempters of yore, Pug was inept, a figure of fun rather than fear. He stood center stage, scratching his horned head, struggling to understand the intricacies of human vice that he was supposed to exploit. His foolishness was immediately apparent as he grappled with the simplest tasks, his exaggerated incompetence drawing hearty laughs from the audience.

Fitzdottrel, a wealthy yet gullible city dweller, soon took the stage. Draped in garish clothes that screamed wealth yet hinted at a lack of taste, Fitzdottrel was the embodiment of Jonson’s satirical lens on the gullible aristocracy. He spoke in lofty tones about his superstitions and gullibility, revealing his willingness to believe in anything that promised more wealth or status. Marrying a beautiful but headstrong young woman, Mistress Frances, Fitzdottrel had become the unwitting target of multiple schemes.

Enter Merecraft and Everill, a duo epitomizing the slippery nature of London’s conmen. Merecraft, with a visage of sharp cunning and a voice smooth as silk, was the mastermind, while Everill, his potbellied sidekick, followed his lead with misplaced confidence. They peddled absurd enterprises—a plot to patent the cure for diseases nobody had, and miraculous investments that promised golden returns. The audience chuckled as Fitzdottrel, wide-eyed and hopeful, naively bought into their elaborate ruses.

As acts shifted, so did the focus. Wittipol, a charming and resourceful young gallant, scaled the play’s moral gradient. Unlike Merecraft, Wittipol was involved in duplicitous schemes but without selfish motives. His disinterested intrigue was a rarity, adding complexity to Jonson’s character-drama. Wittipol sought favorable outcomes but not at the expense of others’ ruin. With his sharp wit and impeccable manners, he became a foil to the darker elements of the play’s comedy.

Lady Tailbush and Lady Eitherside, representing the comedic excesses of the London gentry, brought a clash of semi-political satire and comedy of manners. Each word they spoke was a satirical dart aimed at the absurdity of societal norms and the hollow vanity they cherished. Through their exaggerated affectations, Jonson critiqued the superficiality and pretensions rampant in society. Their scenes, rife with double entendres and biting satire, drew both laughter and reflection from the audience.

In one notable scene, Wittipol and Manly, another upright character, conspired to humiliate Merecraft and Everill. They orchestrated a mock tribunal where Fitzdottrel, realizing his naivety, was forced to confront his folly. The dialogues sparkled with Jonson’s characteristic wit, and the clever character sketches kept the audience enthralled.

The devil-plot, however, stood apart, creating overlapping episodes that disrupted the play’s unity of action. This subplot revolved around Pug’s continuous failures and his eventual realization that human vices were far beyond his elementary understanding. His attempt to corrupt Fitzdottrel comically backfired, with Fitzdottrel proving more adept at deception than the devil himself.

Despite its multiplicity of themes and subplots, the play adhered to the unity of time. The events transpired over a single day, creating an intense interplay of farce and satire. However, the overlapping episodes and lack of clear thematic prioritization made the plot intricate rather than seamless. Jonson crammed the play with so much material that it occasionally felt disjointed, yet it remained a rich tapestry of comedic brilliance.

An unusual aspect of 'The Devil is an Ass' was its language. Written predominantly in blank verse, Jonson sprinkled in varied metrical lines and occasional rough dialogues to portray the characters’ emotional states and social standings. This linguistic variety lent the play a dynamic rhythm, while the satiric dialogues showcased Jonson’s unparalleled mastery over language.

As the final act unfolded, the disparate threads of Wittipol’s intrigue, Merecraft’s schemes, and Pug’s slapstick failures intertwined. The climactic scene saw Fitzdottrel, stripped of his delusions, facing the mock tribunal’s judgment. Pug, acknowledging his defeat, vowed never to set foot on earth again. The curtain fell amid applause, the audience appreciating Jonson’s keen eye for societal critique and his masterful blending of character-driven drama, satire, and comedy.

Though 'The Devil is an Ass' lacked structural coherence, it shone in its satiric dialogue and clever character sketches. It was a reflection of Jonson’s incisive critique of his times, exposing the absurdities and vices of society with comedic flair. As the play ended, the audience recognized it not only as a piece of entertainment but also as a significant historical document, reflective of the societal dynamics of the Jacobean era.

For the main plot we have no direct source. It represents, however, Jonson’s typical method. It has been pointed out([53]) that the characteristic Jonsonian comedy always consists of two groups, the intriguers and the victims. In The Devil is an Ass the most purely comic motive of the play is furnished by a reversal of the usual relation subsisting between these two groups. Here the devil, who was wont to be looked upon as arch-intriguer, is constantly ‘fooled off and beaten’, and thus takes his position as the comic butt. Pug, in a sense, represents a satirical trend. Through him Jonson satirizes the outgrown supernaturalism which still clung to the skirts [xlii]of Jacobean realism, and at the same time paints in lively colors the vice of a society against which hell itself is powerless to contend. It is only, however, in a general way, where the devil stands for a principle, that Pug may be considered as in any degree satirical. In the particular incident he is always a purely comic figure, and furnishes the mirth which results from a sense of the incongruity between anticipation and accomplishment.
Fitzdottrel, on the other hand, is mainly satirical. Through him Jonson passes censure upon the city gallant, the attendant at the theatre, the victim of the prevalent superstitions, and even the pretended demoniac. His dupery, as in the case of his bargain with Wittipol, excites indignation rather than mirth, and his final discomfiture affords us almost a sense of poetic justice. This character stands in the position of chief victim.
In an intermediate position are Merecraft and Everill. They succeed in swindling Fitzdottrel and Lady Tailbush, but are in turn played upon by the chief intriguer, Wittipol, with his friend Manly. Jonson’s moral purpose is here plainly visible, especially in contrast to Plautus, with whom the youthful intriguer is also the stock figure. The motive of the young man’s trickery in the Latin comedy is usually unworthy and selfish. That of Wittipol, on the other hand, is wholly disinterested, since he is represented as having already philosophically accepted the rejection of his advances at the hands of Mrs. Fitzdottrel.
In construction the play suffers from overabundance of material. Instead of a single main line of action, which is given clear precedence, there is rather a succession of elaborated episodes, carefully connected and motivated, but not properly subordinated. The plot is coherent and intricate rather than unified. This is further aggravated by the fact that the chief objects of satire are imperfectly understood by readers of the present day.
Jonson observes unity of time, Pug coming to earth in the morning and returning at midnight. With the exception [xliii]of the first scene, which is indeterminate, and seems at one moment to be hell, and the next London, the action is confined to the City, but hovers between Lincoln’s Inn, Newgate, and the house of Lady Tailbush. Unity of action is of course broken by the interference of the devil-plot and the episodic nature of the satirical plot. The main lines of action may be discussed separately.
In the first act chief prominence is given to the intrigue between Wittipol and Mrs. Fitzdottrel. This interest is continued through the second act, but practically dropped after this point. In Act 4 we find that both lovers have recovered from their infatuation, and the intrigue ends by mutual consent.
The second act opens with the episode of Merecraft’s plot to gull Fitzdottrel. The project of the dukedom of Drownedland is given chief place, and attention is centred upon it both here and in the following scenes. Little use, however, is made of it in the motivation of action. This is left for another project, the office of the Master of Dependencies (quarrels) in the next act. This device is introduced in an incidental way, and we are not prepared for the important place which it takes in the development of the plot. Merecraft, goaded by Everill, hits upon it merely as a temporary makeshift to extort money from Fitzdottrel. The latter determines to make use of the office in prosecuting his quarrel with Wittipol. In preparation for the duel, and in accordance with the course of procedure laid down by Everill, he resolves to settle his estate. Merecraft and Everill endeavor to have the deed drawn in their own favor, but through the interference of Wittipol the whole estate is made over to Manly, who restores it to Mrs. Fitzdottrel. This project becomes then the real turning-point of the play.
The episode of Guilthead and Plutarchus in Act 3 is only slightly connected with the main plot. That of Wittipol’s disguise as a Spanish lady, touched upon in the first two acts, becomes the chief [xliv]interest of the fourth. It furnishes much comic material, and the characters of Lady Tailbush and Lady Eitherside offer the poet the opportunity for some of his cleverest touches in characterization and contrast.([54]) The scene, however, is introduced for incidental purposes, the satirization of foreign fashions and the follies of London society, and is overelaborated. The catalogue of cosmetics is an instance of Jonson’s intimate acquaintance with recondite knowledge standing in the way of his art.
Merecraft’s ‘after game’ in the fifth act is of the nature of an appendix. The play might well have ended with the frustration of his plan to get possession of the estate. This act is introduced chiefly for the sake of a satire upon pretended demoniacs and witch-finders. It also contains the conclusion of the devil-plot.
The Devil is an Ass will always remain valuable as a historical document, and as a record of Jonson’s own attitude towards the abuses of his times. In the treatment of Fitzdottrel and Merecraft among the chief persons, and of Plutarchus Guilthead among the lesser, this play belongs to Jonson’s character-drama.([55]) It does not, however, belong to the pure humor-comedy. Like The Alchemist, and in marked contrast to Every Man out of his Humor, interest is sought in plot development. In the scene between Lady Tailbush and Lady Eitherside, the play becomes a comedy of manners, and in its attack upon state abuses it is semi-political in nature. Both Gifford and Swinburne have observed the ethical treatment of the main motives.
With the exception of Prologue and Epilogue, the doggerel couplets spoken by Iniquity, Wittipol’s song (2. 6. 94), and some of the lines quoted by Fitzdottrel in the last scene, the play is written in blank verse throughout. Occasional lines of eight (2. 2. 122), nine (2. 1. 1), [xlv]twelve (1. 1. 33) or thirteen (1. 1. 113) syllables are introduced. Most of these could easily be normalized by a slight emendation or the slurring of a syllable in pronunciation. Many of the lines, however, are rough and difficult of scansion. Most of the dialogue is vigorous, though Wittipol’s language is sometimes affected and unnatural (cf. Act 1. Sc. 1). His speech, 1. 6. 111-148, is classical in tone, but fragmentary and not perfectly assimilated. The song already referred to possesses delicacy and some beauty of imagery, but lacks Jonson’s customary polish and smoothness.
As a work of art the play must rely chiefly upon the vigor of its satiric dialogue and the cleverness of its character sketches. It lacks the chief excellences of construction—unity of interest, subordination of detail, steady and uninterrupted development, and prompt conclusion.

The passage discusses Ben Jonson's play "The Devil is an Ass," noting the absence of a direct source for the main plot but highlighting Jonson’s typical comedic method involving two groups: the intriguers and the victims. The play is unique in that the devil, Pug, traditionally an arch-intriguer, is instead the comic butt, satirizing outgrown supernatural beliefs and societal vices. Fitzdottrel, mainly satirical, represents various city gallants and prevalent superstitions, becoming the chief victim.

Merecraft and Everill hold an intermediate position, swindling others but also being duped by Wittipol and Manly. Unlike the selfish motives in Plautian comedy, Wittipol’s intrigue is disinterested. The play’s construction suffers from having too much material and lack of clear prioritization, leading to a plot that is intricate rather than unified.

The unity of time is observed, but the unity of action is broken by overlapping episodes and the devil-plot. Each act focuses on different aspects, from Wittipol’s intrigue to Merecraft’s schemes, all leading to varied points of comedic or satirical interest.

The play mixes character-drama, comedy of manners, and semi-political satire, featuring characters like Lady Tailbush and Lady Eitherside. Even though it lacks certain structural excellences, its strength lies in satiric dialogue and clever character sketches. While written predominantly in blank verse, it includes some varied metrical lines and occasional rough dialogues. Overall, the play is significant as a historical document reflecting Jonson's critique of his times.
