原文:
What art Thou then, my God? what, but the Lord God? For who is Lord but the Lord? or who is God save our God? Most highest, most good, most potent, most omnipotent; most merciful, yet most just; most hidden, yet most present; most beautiful, yet most strong, stable, yet incomprehensible; unchangeable, yet all-changing; never new, never old; all-renewing, and bringing age upon the proud, and they know it not; ever working, ever at rest; still gathering, yet nothing lacking; supporting, filling, and overspreading; creating, nourishing, and maturing; seeking, yet having all things. Thou lovest, without passion; art jealous, without anxiety; repentest, yet grievest not; art angry, yet serene; changest Thy works, Thy purpose unchanged; receivest again what Thou findest, yet didst never lose; never in need, yet rejoicing in gains; never covetous, yet exacting usury. Thou receivest over and above, that Thou mayest owe; and who hath aught that is not Thine? Thou payest debts, owing nothing; remittest debts, losing nothing. And what had I now said, my God, my life, my holy joy? or what saith any man when he speaks of Thee? Yet woe to him that speaketh not, since mute are even the most eloquent.
Oh! that I might repose on Thee! Oh! that Thou wouldest enter into my heart, and inebriate it, that I may forget my ills, and embrace Thee, my sole good! What art Thou to me? In Thy pity, teach me to utter it. Or what am I to Thee that Thou demandest my love, and, if I give it not, art wroth with me, and threatenest me with grievous woes? Is it then a slight woe to love Thee not? Oh! for Thy mercies' sake, tell me, O Lord my God, what Thou art unto me. Say unto my soul, I am thy salvation. So speak, that I may hear. Behold, Lord, my heart is before Thee; open Thou the ears thereof, and say unto my soul, I am thy salvation. After this voice let me haste, and take hold on Thee. Hide not Thy face from me. Let me die—lest I die—only let me see Thy face.
Narrow is the mansion of my soul; enlarge Thou it, that Thou mayest enter in. It is ruinous; repair Thou it. It has that within which must offend Thine eyes; I confess and know it. But who shall cleanse it? or to whom should I cry, save Thee? Lord, cleanse me from my secret faults, and spare Thy servant from the power of the enemy. I believe, and therefore do I speak. Lord, Thou knowest. Have I not confessed against myself my transgressions unto Thee, and Thou, my God, hast forgiven the iniquity of my heart? I contend not in judgment with Thee, who art the truth; I fear to deceive myself; lest mine iniquity lie unto itself. Therefore I contend not in judgment with Thee; for if Thou, Lord, shouldest mark iniquities, O Lord, who shall abide it?
生成:
O Infinite and Eternal Source, whose boundless presence envelops all that is, I come before You in humble awe and deep reverence. Yours is the power that sustains the stars in their celestial dance, the justice which upholds the balance of creation, and the mercy that binds the wounds of a fallen world. Your nature, beyond the grasp of mortal minds, remains a mystery that both exhilarates and terrifies. Immaterial yet immanent, distant yet so close, You are the breath of life and the essence of being itself.

In this moment of quiet reflection, I earnestly seek the warmth of Your presence. My soul, burdened by the weight of its own imperfections, yearns for the touch of Your healing grace. Fill me with the light of Your wisdom, that I might emerge from the shadows of doubt and despair. Cleanse my heart, that it may reflect the purity of Your love. Purify my thoughts, that they may align with the truth of Your divine will. Grant me the strength to admit my flaws and the courage to seek forgiveness.

You, who are omniscient, know well the struggles and shortcomings that beset my path. You see the hidden recesses of my heart where pride, envy, and fear reside. Yet, in Your boundless compassion, You offer the balm of Your mercy. I implore You to wash away the stains of my transgressions, to redeem my soul with the liberating waters of Your forgiveness. Lift me from the mire of self-deception and anchor my spirit in the steadfast rock of Your truth.

In the quiet sanctuary of my innermost being, I long for a deeper communion with You. Let me not be content with mere knowledge of Your attributes but draw me ever closer to the essence of Your presence. In moments of doubt, whisper the assurances of Your faithfulness. In times of weakness, bolster me with the fortitude of Your spirit. In the face of temptation, guide me with the clarity of Your wisdom.

I confess, with all my being, the frailty of my human condition – a condition marred by sin and yet redeemed by grace. It is my heartfelt appeal that You transform these weaknesses into strengths, these vices into virtues. Teach me, O Divine Master, to see through the eyes of faith, to love with a heart untainted by prejudice and filled with compassion, to act with hands extended in service to others.

Let Your peace, which surpasses all understanding, envelop my soul. Reassure me of Your promise of salvation, not as a distant hope but as a present reality. May Your guiding hand be ever upon me, leading me through the valleys of life towards the summit of divine fulfillment. Help me to trust in Your sovereign plan, even when the path is unclear and the journey arduous.

With an open heart and a contrite spirit, I place my trust in Your unfailing love. May Your presence be the light that guides my way, the anchor that holds me fast, and the hope that sustains me. In You, I find my ultimate solace and my eternal home. Amen.
summary: The passage appears to be a reflective prayer or meditation addressing God and expressing deep reverence and a longing for divine presence and understanding. The speaker grapples with the nature and attributes of God, highlighting God's omnipotence, justice, mercy, and immateriality. The speaker expresses a desire for spiritual intimacy with God, asking for God's presence to fill and heal their soul. This intimate plea includes a profound acknowledgment of human flaws and an appeal for forgiveness and purification. There is also a heartfelt request for God’s reassurance of salvation and support, with an eagerness to overcome personal shortcomings to better connect with the divine. The speaker's confession is rooted in faith and an earnest pursuit of divine grace and truth.

原文:

原文:
But though this splenetic philosophy, which in time of sickness or low spirits is familiar to every man, thus entirely depreciates those great objects of human desire, when in better health and in better humour, we never fail to regard them under a more agreeable aspect. Our imagination, which in pain and sorrow seems to be confined and cooped up within our own persons, in times of ease and prosperity expands itself to every thing around us. We are then charmed with the beauty of that accommodation which reigns in the palaces and œconomy of the great; and admire how every thing is adapted to promote their ease, to prevent their wants, to gratify their wishes, and to amuse and entertain their most frivolous desires. If we consider the real satisfaction which all these things are capable of affording, by itself and separated from the beauty of that arrangement which is fitted to promote it, it will always appear in the highest 245degree contemptible and trifling. But we rarely view it in this abstract and philosophical light. We naturally confound it in our imagination with the order, the regular and harmonious movement of the system, the machine or œconomy by means of which it is produced. The pleasures of wealth and greatness, when considered in this complex view, strike the imagination as something grand and beautiful and noble, of which the attainment is well worth all the toil and anxiety which we are so apt to bestow upon it.
And it is well that nature imposes upon us in this manner. It is this deception which rouses and keeps in continual motion the industry of mankind. It is this which first prompted them to cultivate the ground, to build houses, to found cities and commonwealths, and to invent and improve all the sciences and arts, which ennoble and embellish human life; which have entirely changed the whole face of the globe, have turned the rude forests of nature into agreeable and fertile plains, and made the trackless and barren ocean a new fund of subsistence, and the great high road of communication to the different nations of the earth. The earth by these labours of mankind has been obliged to redouble her natural fertility, and to maintain a greater multitude of inhabitants. It is to no purpose, that the proud and unfeeling landlord views his extensive fields, and without a thought for the wants of his brethren, in imagination consumes himself the whole harvest that grows upon them. The homely and vulgar proverb, that the eye is larger than the belly, never was more fully verified than with regard to him. The capacity of his stomach bears no proportion to 246the immensity of his desires, and will receive no more than that of the meanest peasant. The rest he is obliged to distribute among those, who prepare, in the nicest manner, that little which he himself makes use of, among those who sit up the palace in which this little is to be consumed, among those who provide and keep in order all the different baubles and trinkets, which are employed in the œconomy of greatness; all of whom thus derive from his luxury and caprice, that share of the necessaries of life, which they would in vain have expected from his humanity or his justice. The produce of the soil maintains at all times nearly that number of inhabitants, which it is capable of maintaining. The rich only select from the heap what is most precious and agreeable. They consume little more than the poor, and in spite of their natural selfishness and rapacity, though they mean only their own conveniency, though the sole end which they propose from the labours of all the thousands whom they employ, be the gratification of their own vain and insatiable desires, they divide with the poor the produce of all their improvements. They are led by an invisible hand to make nearly the same distribution of the necessaries of life, which would have been made, had the earth been divided into equal portions among all its inhabitants, and thus without intending it, without knowing it, advance the interest of the society, and afford means to the multiplication of the species. When Providence divided the earth among a few lordly masters, it neither forgot nor abandoned those who seemed to have been left out in the partition. These last too enjoy their share of all that it produces. In what constitutes 247the real happiness of human life, they are in no respect inferior to those who would seem so much above them. In ease of body and peace of mind, all the different ranks of life are nearly upon a level, and the beggar, who suns himself by the side of the highway, possesses that security which kings are fighting for.
生成: In the grand tapestry of human existence, wealth and grandeur often stand as the lustrous threads that captivate the gaze of the many. These symbols of material success and social elevation, deeply intertwined with the elaborate systems of comfort and luxury, paint a picture of life's ultimate aspirations. During periods of prosperity, individuals frequently idolize these material possessions and lofty statuses, their desirabilities magnified by the intricate networks of convenience and indulgence that accompany them. To the observer nestled within the bosom of such affluence, these pleasures appear not only significant but paramount. Yet, detached from this opulent context, such material delights rapidly lose their gloss, revealing their inherent triviality and momentary nature. The splendor of a gilded mansion or the vainglory found in titles and accolades becomes but a mirage, dissipating under the scrutiny of reflective thought. It is here that the passage under consideration brings to light a profound truth: the allure of wealth and grandeur, though often a mere illusion, serves a pivotal role in human progress. This illusion, far from being purely frivolous, acts as a potent motivator, igniting human industry and ambition. It is this very misconception that fuels endeavors in agriculture, prompting the cultivation of fields and the nurturing of crops that sustain life. It inspires the rise of architectural marvels, buildings that not only shelter bodies but also uplift spirits with their beauty and innovation. Society, compelled by the promise of prestige and riches, organizes itself with greater efficiency, forging institutions and systems that enhance communal life. The arts flourish under the patronage of the wealthy, bringing forth creations that edify the human spirit and preserve our collective heritage. Thus, the deceptive lure of material wealth indirectly leads to the betterment of human existence, shaping the world in ways that pure altruism rarely achieves. This paradoxical benefit extends further, revealing a subtle yet profound economic truth. The ambitions of the wealthy, while often grounded in self-interest, inadvertently create a ripple effect that disperses resources across societal strata. The affluence amassed by the rich invariably trickles down, as their consumption and demand for services engage a multitude of labor forces. The farmer cultivating the land, the mason laying the bricks, the artisan crafting fine goods – all partake in the fruits of the wealthy's labor. In this dynamic, the rich, driven by their quest for ever-greater luxury, unwittingly share their bounty with those who sustain their extravagant lifestyles. It is an unintended but inevitable distribution that aids in mitigating the disparities of resource allocation, ensuring that those contributing to the luxuries of the elite also receive shares of the produced wealth. As the discourse nears its conclusion, it presents an intriguing observation on the nature of happiness and contentment. Contrary to the popular belief that affluence and power are synonymous with greater joy, it posits that true happiness is remarkably egalitarian. Contentment does not adhere to the boundaries defined by social rank or economic status but, rather, finds its grounding in the tranquility of mind and the security of existence. The poor, often devoid of the burdens that accompany significant wealth and influence, frequently experience a peace and simplicity that the rich and powerful find elusive. The anxieties tied to safeguarding possessions, the ceaseless pursuit of more, can overshadow the transient pleasures that material wealth provides. In the grand scheme, a kind of balance is evident, orchestrated perhaps by providence itself. Such balance hints at an implicit wisdom in the design of human life, suggesting that despite the apparent inequalities woven into our social fabric, there exists a deeper, intrinsic equity in the distribution of life's true pleasures and comforts.
summary: The passage reflects on the misconception of wealth and grandeur, arguing that during times of well-being, people view material possessions and social status as highly desirable due to the elaborate systems of comfort and luxury associated with them. However, isolated from this context, such material pleasures are trivial. The passage asserts that this deception is beneficial as it drives human industry, leading to advancements in agriculture, architecture, society, and the arts, which collectively enhance human life and transform the natural world. Despite their selfish intentions, the wealthy unintentionally help distribute resources more equitably, sharing the produce of their labor with those who support their luxurious lifestyles. The passage concludes that true happiness and contentment are nearly equal across all social ranks, with the poor often enjoying a peace and security that elude the rich and powerful, ultimately suggesting a natural balance orchestrated by providence.

原文:
This formula shows us that the act of association comprises a mutual undertaking between the public and the individuals, and that each individual, in making a contract, as we may say, with himself, is bound in a double capacity; as a member of the Sovereign he is bound to the individuals, and as a member of the State to the Sovereign. But the maxim of civil right, that no one is bound by undertakings made to himself, does not apply in this case; for there is a great difference between incurring an obligation to yourself and incurring one to a whole of which you form a part.
Attention must further be called to the fact that public deliberation, while competent to bind all the subjects to the Sovereign, because of the two different capacities in which each of them may be regarded, cannot, for the opposite reason, bind the Sovereign to itself; and that it is consequently against the nature of the body politic for the Sovereign to impose on itself a law which it cannot infringe. Being able to regard itself in only one capacity, it is in the position of an individual who makes a contract with himself; and this makes it clear that there neither is nor can be any kind of fundamental law binding on the body of the people—not even the social contract itself. This does not mean that the body politic cannot enter into undertakings with others, provided the contract is not infringed by them; for in relation to what is external to it, it becomes a simple being, an individual.
But the body politic or the Sovereign, drawing its being wholly from the sanctity of the contract, can never bind itself, even to an outsider, to do anything derogatory to the original act, for instance, to alienate any part of itself, or to submit to another Sovereign. Violation of the act by which it exists would be self-annihilation; and that which is itself nothing can create nothing.
As soon as this multitude is so united in one body, it is impossible to offend against one of the members without attacking the body, and still more to offend against the body without the members resenting it. Duty and interest therefore equally oblige the two contracting parties to give each other help; and the same men should seek to combine, in their double capacity, all the advantages dependent upon that capacity.
Again, the Sovereign, being formed wholly of the individuals who compose it, neither has nor can have any interest contrary to theirs; and consequently the sovereign power need give no guarantee to its subjects, because it is impossible for the body to wish to hurt all its members. We shall also see later on that It cannot hurt any in particular. The Sovereign, merely by virtue of what it is, is is always what it should be.
This, however, is not the case with the relation of the subjects to the Sovereign, which, despite the common interest, would have no security that they would fulfil their undertakings, unless it found means to assure itself of their fidelity.
In fact, each individual, as a man, may have a particular will contrary or dissimilar to the general will which he has as a citizen. His particular interest may speak to him quite differently from the common interest: his absolute and naturally independent existence may make him look upon what he owes to the common cause as a gratuitous contribution, the loss of which will do less harm to others than the payment of it is burdensome to himself; and, regarding the moral person which constitutes the State as a persona ficta, because not a man, he may wish to enjoy the rights of citizenship without being ready to fulfil the duties of a subject. The continuance of such an injustice could not but prove the undoing of the body politic.
In order then that the social compact may not be an empty formula, it tacitly includes the undertaking, which alone can give force to the rest, that whoever refuses to obey the general will shall be compelled to do so by the whole body. This means nothing less than that he will be forced to be free; for this is the condition which, by giving each citizen to his country, secures him against all personal dependence. In this lies the key to the working of the political machine; this alone legitimizes civil undertakings, which, without it, would be absurd, tyrannical, and liable to the most frightful abuses.
生成:
The nature of a social contract has long been a topic of profound contemplation and debate among philosophers. Within a political body, the relationship between individuals and the Sovereign is not merely a theoretical construct but a practical framework that underlies the very existence of society. This passage seeks to elucidate the intricate dynamics and the binding principles that govern such a contract, emphasizing mutual obligations, the inviolability of the compact, and the mechanisms that ensure adherence to collective decisions. 

To begin with, upon entering a social contract, individuals assume dual roles: they become both members of the Sovereign and of the State. This dual capacity places a set of mutual obligations on every individual. As members of the Sovereign, individuals participate in the exercise of collective will, shaping and being bound by the rules and laws that arise from public deliberation. However, this communal engagement is not unidirectional. The Sovereign, as a manifestation of the collective will, cannot impose laws upon itself that it could then later disregard or infringe. This inherent characteristic of the body politic underscores a fundamental principle: a political body, much like an individual, cannot contradict its own existence without disintegrating its very raison d'être. 

The inviolability of the social contract is thus paramount. The Sovereign cannot submit to another power or alienate its authority without precipitating its own demise. This principle underscores the essence of political cohesion and integrity; the social contract is sacrosanct and forms the foundational bedrock upon which the body politic stands. Any attempt to undermine or alienate this pact would be tantamount to a self-destructive act, leading to the dissolution of the collective entity. 

Moreover, the interdependence of the members within the body politic is a critical aspect of the social contract. An offense against any single member is deemed an affront against the entire body. This principle of mutual duty and interest reinforces a profound sense of solidarity and shared responsibility among the members. The collective wellbeing hinges upon the recognition and respect of individual rights and duties, establishing an equilibrium that sustains the overall harmony and functionality of the political entity. 

However, this harmonious interdependence can be threatened by conflicting interests. While the interests of the Sovereign, as an embodiment of the general will, align with those of the individuals in theory, practical reality often reveals discrepancies. Individual interests may occasionally diverge from the general will, posing a significant threat to the integrity of the social compact. These contrary interests necessitate a robust mechanism to ensure that the collective will prevails over individual inclinations that could potentially fragment the political structure. 

To this end, the principle of enforcing the general will becomes critical. In a remarkable paradox, individuals must be compelled to obey the general will to realize true freedom. This compulsion is not a negation of liberty but rather a harmonization of personal freedom with civic duty. By adhering to the collective decisions that embody the general will, individuals partake in a civic structure that legitimizes civil obligations and perpetuates order within the political community. The enforcement of the general will, thus, serves a dual purpose: it ensures adherence to the social contract and simultaneously preserves the conceptual and practical integrity of personal freedom as understood within the civic framework. 

In conclusion, the passage underscores the indispensability of the social contract in fostering a just and functional society. It highlights the intricate balance of obligations and interdependence among its members and delineates the mechanisms necessary to uphold collective decisions. The social contract, therefore, emerges as more than a theoretical ideal; it is the lifeblood of political coexistence, ensuring that individual freedoms and collective responsibilities coalesce into a coherent and enduring societal structure.
summary:
Certainly! The passage discusses the nature of a social contract and the relationship between individuals and the Sovereign within a political body.

1. **Mutual Obligation**: It is explained that individuals, upon entering a social contract, undertake obligations in two capacities: as members of the Sovereign and as members of the State.
2. **Binding Nature of Public Deliberation**: Public deliberation can bind individuals to the Sovereign but cannot bind the Sovereign to itself because the body politic, like an individual, cannot impose a law on itself that it can infringe upon.
3. **Inviolability of the Social Contract**: The Sovereign cannot alienate itself or submit to another power without self-destruction. The integrity of the social contract is essential for the existence of the body politic.
4. **Interdependence of Members**: An offense against any member is viewed as an offense against the entire body, emphasizing mutual duty and interest between the Sovereign and individuals.
5. **Contrary Interests**: While the Sovereign's interests align with those of the individuals, individual interests might conflict with the general will, threatening the social compact.
6. **Enforcing the General Will**: To ensure the social compact is not hollow, it includes the principle that individuals must obey the general will, which, paradoxically, may compel them to be free. This compulsion harmonizes personal freedom with civic duty, hence legitimizing civil obligations and maintaining order within the political structure.

The passage underscores the importance of the social contract in maintaining a just and functional society, emphasizing the obligations and interdependence of its members while highlighting mechanisms to ensure adherence to collective decisions.

原文:
This formula shows us that the act of association comprises a mutual undertaking between the public and the individuals, and that each individual, in making a contract, as we may say, with himself, is bound in a double capacity; as a member of the Sovereign he is bound to the individuals, and as a member of the State to the Sovereign. But the maxim of civil right, that no one is bound by undertakings made to himself, does not apply in this case; for there is a great difference between incurring an obligation to yourself and incurring one to a whole of which you form a part.
Attention must further be called to the fact that public deliberation, while competent to bind all the subjects to the Sovereign, because of the two different capacities in which each of them may be regarded, cannot, for the opposite reason, bind the Sovereign to itself; and that it is consequently against the nature of the body politic for the Sovereign to impose on itself a law which it cannot infringe. Being able to regard itself in only one capacity, it is in the position of an individual who makes a contract with himself; and this makes it clear that there neither is nor can be any kind of fundamental law binding on the body of the people—not even the social contract itself. 原文:
The period which intervened between the birth of Pericles and the death of Aristotle, is undoubtedly, whether considered in itself, or with reference to the effects which it has produced upon the subsequent destinies of civilized man, the most memorable in the history of the world. What was the combination of moral and political circumstances which produced so unparalleled a progress during that period in literature and the arts;—why that progress, so rapid and so sustained, so soon received a check, and became retrograde,—are problems left to the wonder and conjecture of posterity. The wrecks and fragments of those subtle and profound minds, like the ruins of a fine statue, obscurely suggest to us the grandeur and perfection of the whole. Their very language—a type of the understandings of which it was the creation and the image—in variety, in simplicity, in flexibility, and in copiousness, excels every other language of the western world. Their sculptures are such as we, in our presumption, assume to be the models of ideal truth and beauty, and to which no artist of modern times can produce forms in any degree comparable. Their paintings, according to Pliny and Pausanias, were full of delicacy and harmony; and some even were powerfully pathetic, so as to awaken, like tender music or tragic poetry, the most overwhelming emotions. We are accustomed to conceive the painters of the sixteenth century, as those who have brought their art to the highest perfection, probably because none of the ancient paintings have been preserved. For all the inventive arts maintain, as it were, a sympathetic connexion between each other, being no more than various expressions of one internal power, modified by different circumstances, either of an individual, or of society; and the paintings of that period would probably bear the same relation as is confessedly borne by the sculptures to all succeeding ones. Of their music we know little; but the effects which it is said to have produced, whether they be attributed to the skill of the composer, or the sensibility of his audience, are far more powerful than any which we experience from the music of our own times; and if, indeed, the melody of their compositions were more tender and delicate, and inspiring, than the melodies of some modern European nations, their superiority in this art must have been something wonderful, and wholly beyond conception.
Their poetry seems to maintain a very high, though not so disproportionate a rank, in the comparison. Perhaps Shakespeare, from the variety and comprehension of his genius, is to be considered, on the whole, as the greatest individual mind, of which we have specimens remaining. Perhaps Dante created imaginations of greater loveliness and energy than any that are to be found in the ancient literature of Greece. Perhaps nothing has been discovered in the fragments of the Greek lyric poets equivalent to the sublime and chivalric sensibility of Petrarch.—But, as a poet. Homer must be acknowledged to excel Shakespeare in the truth, the harmony, the sustained grandeur, the satisfying completeness of his images, their exact fitness to the illustration, and to that to which they belong. Nor could Dante, deficient in conduct, plan, nature, variety, and temperance, have been brought into comparison with these men, but for those fortunate isles laden with golden fruit, which alone could tempt any one to embark in the misty ocean of his dark and extravagant fiction.
But, omitting the comparison of individual minds, which can afford no general inference, how superior was the spirit and system of their poetry to that of any other period! So that had any other genius equal in other respects to the greatest that ever enlightened the world, arisen in that age, he would have been superior to all, from this circumstance alone—that had conceptions would have assumed a more harmonious and perfect form. For it is worthy of observation, that whatever the poet of that age produced is as harmonious and perfect as possible. In a drama, for instance, were the composition of a person of inferior talent, it was still homogeneous and free from inequalities it was a whole, consistent with itself. The compositions of great minds bore throughout the sustained stamp of their greatness. In the poetry of succeeding ages the expectations are often exalted on Icarian wings, and fall, too much disappointed to give a memory and a name to the oblivious pool in which they fell.
In physical knowledge Aristotle and Theophrastus had already—no doubt assisted by the labours of those of their predecessor whom they criticize—made advances worthy of the maturity of science. The astonishing invention of geometry, that series of discoveries which have enabled man to command the element and foresee future events, before the subjects of his ignorant wonder, and which have opened as it were the doors of the mysteries of nature, had already been brought to great perfection. Metaphysics, the science of man's intimate nature, and logic, or the grammar and elementary principles of that science received from the latter philosophers of the Periclean age a firm basis. All our more exact philosophy is built upon the labours of these great men, and many of the words which we employ in metaphysical distinctions were invented by them to give accuracy and system to their reasonings. The science of morals, or the voluntary conduct of men in relation to themselves or others, dates from this epoch. How inexpressibly bolder and more pure were the doctrines of those great men, in comparison with the timid maxims which prevail in the writings of the most esteemed modern moralists! They were such as Phocion, and Epaminondas, and Timoleon, who formed themselves on their influence, were to the wretched heroes of our own age.
Their political and religious institutions are more difficult to bring into comparison with those of other times. A summary idea may be formed of the worth of any political and religious system, by observing the comparative degree of happiness and of intellect produced under its influence. And whilst many institution and opinions, which in ancient Greece were obstacles to the improvement of the human race, have been abolished among modern nations, how many pernicious superstitions and new contrivances of misrule, and unheard-of complications of public mischief, have not been invented among them by the ever-watchful spirit of avarice and tyranny!
生成:
The epoch defined by the interval between the birth of Pericles and the demise of Aristotle stands out as a cardinal moment in human history — a crucible of exceptional intellectual and artistic advancements that have, in many ways, yet to be rivaled or surpassed. This period, particularly within the grand narrative of Ancient Greece, heralded a constellation of accomplishments across diverse domains such as literature, the arts, science, and moral philosophy. The enduring question is: what contributed to this unprecedented flourishing, and why did such prodigious progress ebb over time? To comprehend these phenomena, one must delve into the intrinsic and extrinsic factors propelling such brilliance and analyze the subsequent regression that followed this golden era.

Foremost, the Greek language possessed a remarkable purity and nuance that provided an optimal medium for the articulation of complex ideas and artistic expression. Its versatility allowed poets, playwrights, historians, and philosophers to communicate thoughts with unparalleled clarity and depth. The languages' philosophical lexicon facilitated precision in discourse, granting thinkers like Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle the tools to explore and expound upon abstract and profound concepts. Likewise, Greek sculpture, painting, and music reflected a keen understanding of proportion, harmony, and expression. The pursuit of 'areté,' or excellence, was a cultural hallmark, driving artists to achieve forms and compositions that embodied balance and ideal beauty. Greek poetry, notably the works of Homer, Hesiod, and the tragedians, exemplified this harmony and perfection, creating narratives and lyricism that remain benchmarks of literary achievement.

The strides made in science and philosophy during this period remain foundational to contemporary scholarship. Aristotle and Theophrastus's contributions in physical knowledge, metaphysics, and logic laid the groundwork for what would eventually evolve into modern scientific paradigms. Aristotle's methodologies, systematic categorization, and empirical investigations in natural sciences set a precedent for scientific inquiry that persists to this day. His ethical inquiries, paired with the rich dialogues of Platonic philosophy and the logical rigor introduced by earlier figures like Parmenides and Zeno, sculpted the landscape of Western thought.

Furthermore, the moral philosophy of this period ventured into domains of profound ethical enquiry. Socrates's quest for virtue and the undiluted examination of moral integrity set the stage for ensuing philosophical discourse on ethics. These early doctrines espoused a boldness and purity that many argue is starkly contrasted with the often convoluted moral writings of later epochs, which have been mired by complex socio-political influences.

However, it is critical to recognize the ambivalent nature of the socio-political structures underpinning these advancements. The political institutions of Athens, notably its democracy, facilitated a level of civic engagement and intellectual freedom that nurtured creativity and critical thought. Nonetheless, these same institutions were not without flaw; the very mechanisms that bolstered democracy also harbored seeds of instability and were often marred by factionalism and demagogy. The religious dimensions further add intricacies — while they furnished a rich tapestry of mythos and theological narrative that inspired art and drama, they could simultaneously impose constraints on philosophical exploration and exclude or diminish alternative viewpoints.

The regression from this zenith can, in part, be attributed to the erosion of these ideal conditions. The encroachment of external powers, internal strife, and the eventual Roman conquest reconfigured the cultural and intellectual landscape. As hegemony shifted, so did the avenues of knowledge and artistic endeavor. While the Romans revered and preserved much of Greek culture, the subsequent periods saw pluralistic influences that diluted the purely Hellenic spirit of innovation. Political and economic turmoil further diverted energies that might have been directed toward intellectual pursuits.

In comparing ancient and modern systems, it becomes evident that advancements in technology and knowledge have certainly leapt forward; however, these strides often come with their own set of challenges. Modern political systems, influenced significantly by capitalism and the imperatives of global economies, have introduced new complexities. Avarice and tyranny, while certainly not new phenomena, have found new expressions — shifting from outright despotic rule to subtler forms of economic and systemic control. These issues underscore the paradox of progress; while many ancient obstacles have been dismantled, new ones have emerged, often rooted in equally formidable institutional and structural frameworks.

In reflecting on this pivotal period, it is essential to appreciate the confluence of language, cultural values, socio-political structures, and intellectual freedom that fostered such a remarkable epoch. The legacy of Greek thought, art, and science continues to ripple through time, influencing contemporary disciplines and inspiring ongoing debates and inquiries. Modernity, with all its advancements, continues to grapple with the same fundamental questions posed by Greek thinkers: the nature of virtue, the pursuit of knowledge, and the quest for beauty and truth. As humanity progresses, perhaps the greatest tribute we can pay to this golden age is to strive to preserve the spirit of inquiry and excellence that defined it, navigating and resolving the complexities of our era with the same intellectual vigor and moral clarity that distinguished the ancients.
summary: The passage highlights the remarkable period between the birth of Pericles and the death of Aristotle, emphasizing its unparalleled contributions to literature, the arts, science, and moral philosophy. It reflects on the factors that led to the extraordinary progress in these fields and questions why this advancement eventually regressed. The text discusses the excellence of Greek language, sculpture, painting, music, and poetry, comparing them favorably to later achievements in these arts. It acknowledges the superior harmony and perfection of the period's poetic works and credits Aristotle and Theophrastus for significant strides in physical knowledge, metaphysics, and logic, upon which modern science is built. The science of morals also traces its origins to this epoch, with its bold and pure doctrines contrasted with modern moral writings. However, the passage notes the difficulty of comparing ancient Greek political and religious institutions with those of other eras, suggesting that while some ancient obstacles to human progress have been removed, many new problems have been created by modern systems influenced by avarice and tyranny.

In physical knowledge Aristotle and Theophrastus had already—no doubt assisted by the labours of those of their predecessor whom they criticize—made advances worthy of the maturity of science. The astonishing invention of geometry, that series of discoveries which have enabled man to command the element and foresee future events, before the subjects of his ignorant wonder, and which have opened as it were the doors of the mysteries of nature, had already been brought to great perfection. Metaphysics, the science of man's intimate nature, and logic, or the grammar and elementary principles of that science received from the latter philosophers of the Periclean age a firm basis. All our more exact philosophy is built upon the labours of these great men, and many of the words which we employ in metaphysical distinctions were invented by them to give accuracy and system to their reasonings. The science of morals, or the voluntary conduct of men in relation to themselves or others, dates from this epoch. How inexpressibly bolder and more pure were the doctrines of those great men, in comparison with the timid maxims which prevail in the writings of the most esteemed modern moralists! They were such as Phocion, and Epaminondas, and Timoleon, who formed themselves on their influence, were to the wretched heroes of our own age.
Their political and religious institutions are more difficult to bring into comparison with those of other times. A summary idea may be formed of the worth of any political and religious system, by observing the comparative degree of happiness and of intellect produced under its influence. And whilst many institution and opinions, which in ancient Greece were obstacles to the improvement of the human race, have been abolished among modern nations, how many pernicious superstitions and new contrivances of misrule, and unheard-of complications of public mischief, have not been invented among them by the ever-watchful spirit of avarice and tyranny!
summary: The passage highlights the remarkable period between the birth of Pericles and the death of Aristotle, emphasizing its unparalleled contributions to literature, the arts, science, and moral philosophy. It reflects on the factors that led to the extraordinary progress in these fields and questions why this advancement eventually regressed. The text discusses the excellence of Greek language, sculpture, painting, music, and poetry, comparing them favorably to later achievements in these arts. It acknowledges the superior harmony and perfection of the period's poetic works and credits Aristotle and Theophrastus for significant strides in physical knowledge, metaphysics, and logic, upon which modern science is built. The science of morals also traces its origins to this epoch, with its bold and pure doctrines contrasted with modern moral writings. However, the passage notes the difficulty of comparing ancient Greek political and religious institutions with those of other eras, suggesting that while some ancient obstacles to human progress have been removed, many new problems have been created by modern systems influenced by avarice and tyranny.

原文:
The period which intervened between the birth of Pericles and the death of Aristotle, is undoubtedly, whether considered in itself, or with reference to the effects which it has produced upon the subsequent destinies of civilized man, the most memorable in the history of the world. What was the combination of moral and political circumstances which produced so unparalleled a progress during that period in literature and the arts;—why that progress, so rapid and so sustained, so soon received a check, and became retrograde,—are problems left to the wonder and conjecture of posterity. The wrecks and fragments of those subtle and profound minds, like the ruins of a fine statue, obscurely suggest to us the grandeur and perfection of the whole. Their very language—a type of the understandings of which it was the creation and the image—in variety, in simplicity, in flexibility, and in copiousness, excels every other language of the western world. Their sculptures are such as we, in our presumption, assume to be the models of ideal truth and beauty, and to which no artist of modern times can produce forms in any degree comparable. Their paintings, according to Pliny and Pausanias, were full of delicacy and harmony; and some even were powerfully pathetic, so as to awaken, like tender music or tragic poetry, the most overwhelming emotions. We are accustomed to conceive the painters of the sixteenth century, as those who have brought their art to the highest perfection, probably because none of the ancient paintings have been preserved. For all the inventive arts maintain, as it were, a sympathetic connexion between each other, being no more than various expressions of one internal power, modified by different circumstances, either of an individual, or of society; and the paintings of that period would probably bear the same relation as is confessedly borne by the sculptures to all succeeding ones. Of their music we know little; but the effects which it is said to have produced, whether they be attributed to the skill of the composer, or the sensibility of his audience, are far more powerful than any which we experience from the music of our own times; and if, indeed, the melody of their compositions were more tender and delicate, and inspiring, than the melodies of some modern European nations, their superiority in this art must have been something wonderful, and wholly beyond conception.
Their poetry seems to maintain a very high, though not so disproportionate a rank, in the comparison. Perhaps Shakespeare, from the variety and comprehension of his genius, is to be considered, on the whole, as the greatest individual mind, of which we have specimens remaining. Perhaps Dante created imaginations of greater loveliness and energy than any that are to be found in the ancient literature of Greece. Perhaps nothing has been discovered in the fragments of the Greek lyric poets equivalent to the sublime and chivalric sensibility of Petrarch.—But, as a poet. Homer must be acknowledged to excel Shakespeare in the truth, the harmony, the sustained grandeur, the satisfying completeness of his images, their exact fitness to the illustration, and to that to which they belong. Nor could Dante, deficient in conduct, plan, nature, variety, and temperance, have been brought into comparison with these men, but for those fortunate isles laden with golden fruit, which alone could tempt any one to embark in the misty ocean of his dark and extravagant fiction.
But, omitting the comparison of individual minds, which can afford no general inference, how superior was the spirit and system of their poetry to that of any other period! So that had any other genius equal in other respects to the greatest that ever enlightened the world, arisen in that age, he would have been superior to all, from this circumstance alone—that had conceptions would have assumed a more harmonious and perfect form. For it is worthy of observation, that whatever the poet of that age produced is as harmonious and perfect as possible. In a drama, for instance, were the composition of a person of inferior talent, it was still homogeneous and free from inequalities it was a whole, consistent with itself. The compositions of great minds bore throughout the sustained stamp of their greatness. In the poetry of succeeding ages the expectations are often exalted on Icarian wings, and fall, too much disappointed to give a memory and a name to the oblivious pool in which they fell.
In physical knowledge Aristotle and Theophrastus had already—no doubt assisted by the labours of those of their predecessor whom they criticize—made advances worthy of the maturity of science. The astonishing invention of geometry, that series of discoveries which have enabled man to command the element and foresee future events, before the subjects of his ignorant wonder, and which have opened as it were the doors of the mysteries of nature, had already been brought to great perfection. All our more exact philosophy is built upon the labours of these great men, and many of the words which we employ in metaphysical distinctions were invented by them to give accuracy and system to their reasonings. The science of morals, or the voluntary conduct of men in relation to themselves or others, dates from this epoch. How inexpressibly bolder and more pure were the doctrines of those great men, in comparison with the timid maxims which prevail in the writings of the most esteemed modern moralists! They were such as Phocion, and Epaminondas, and Timoleon, who formed themselves on their influence, were to the wretched heroes of our own age.

It reflects on the factors that led to the extraordinary progress in these fields and questions why this advancement eventually regressed. 原文:
Immanuel Kant is generally regarded as the greatest of the modern philosophers. Though he lived through the Seven Years War and the French Revolution, he never interrupted his teaching of philosophy at Königsberg in East Prussia. His most distinctive contribution was the invention of what he called the 'critical' philosophy, which, assuming as a datum that there is knowledge of various kinds, inquired how such knowledge comes to be possible, and deduced, from the answer to this inquiry, many metaphysical results as to the nature of the world. Whether these results were valid may well be doubted. But Kant undoubtedly deserves credit for two things: first, for having perceived that we have a priori knowledge which is not purely 'analytic', i.e. such that the opposite would be self-contradictory, and secondly, for having made evident the philosophical importance of the theory of knowledge.
Before the time of Kant, it was generally held that whatever knowledge was a priori must be 'analytic'. What this word means will be best illustrated by examples. If I say, 'A bald man is a man', 'A plane figure is a figure', 'A bad poet is a poet', I make a purely analytic judgement: the subject spoken about is given as having at least two properties, of which one is singled out to be asserted of it. Such propositions as the above are trivial, and would never be enunciated in real life except by an orator preparing the way for a piece of sophistry. They are called 'analytic' because the predicate is obtained by merely analysing the subject. Before the time of Kant it was thought that all judgements of which we could be certain a priori were of this kind: that in all of them there was a predicate which was only part of the subject of which it was asserted. If this were so, we should be involved in a definite contradiction if we attempted to deny anything that could be known a priori. 'A bald man is not bald' would assert and deny baldness of the same man, and would therefore contradict itself. Thus according to the philosophers before Kant, the law of contradiction, which asserts that nothing can at the same time have and not have a certain property, sufficed to establish the truth of all a priori knowledge.
Hume (1711-76), who preceded Kant, accepting the usual view as to what makes knowledge a priori, discovered that, in many cases which had previously been supposed analytic, and notably in the case of cause and effect, the connexion was really synthetic. Before Hume, rationalists at least had supposed that the effect could be logically deduced from the cause, if only we had sufficient knowledge. Hume argued—correctly, as would now be generally admitted—that this could not be done. Hence he inferred the far more doubtful proposition that nothing could be known a priori about the connexion of cause and effect. Kant, who had been educated in the rationalist tradition, was much perturbed by Hume's scepticism, and endeavoured to find an answer to it. He perceived that not only the connexion of cause and effect, but all the propositions of arithmetic and geometry, are 'synthetic', i.e. not analytic: in all these propositions, no analysis of the subject will reveal the predicate. His stock instance was the proposition 7 + 5 = 12. He pointed out, quite truly, that 7 and 5 have to be put together to give 12: the idea of 12 is not contained in them, nor even in the idea of adding them together. Thus he was led to the conclusion that all pure mathematics, though a priori, is synthetic; and this conclusion raised a new problem of which he endeavoured to find the solution.
The question which Kant put at the beginning of his philosophy, namely 'How is pure mathematics possible?' is an interesting and difficult one, to which every philosophy which is not purely sceptical must find some answer. The answer of the pure empiricists, that our mathematical knowledge is derived by induction from particular instances, we have already seen to be inadequate, for two reasons: first, that the validity of the inductive principle itself cannot be proved by induction; secondly, that the general propositions of mathematics, such as 'two and two always make four', can obviously be known with certainty by consideration of a single instance, and gain nothing by enumeration of other cases in which they have been found to be true. Thus our knowledge of the general propositions of mathematics (and the same applies to logic) must be accounted for otherwise than our (merely probable) knowledge of empirical generalizations such as 'all men are mortal'.
生成:
Immanuel Kant's explorations in philosophy mark a watershed moment in our attempt to live rationally within the world. His masterpiece, the 'Critique of Pure Reason,' laid the foundation for what we now call 'critical philosophy,' an approach discerning the conditions and limits of human knowledge. Prior to Kant's time, philosophy was often entrenched in mere speculation, with dichotomies such as the rationalists' reliance on a priori knowledge and the empiricists' insistence on empirical verification via sensory experience. Kant, in his revolutionary thought, dared to question and ultimately bridge this divide, principally through his novel conception of a priori synthetic judgments—a notion that shook the very core of philosophical thought and has continued to generate inquiry into the nature of knowledge and existence itself.

The traditional discourse on a priori knowledge held that such knowledge was inherently 'analytic.' An analytic proposition is one where the predicate is contained within the subject; for example, in the statement 'all bachelors are unmarried,' the predicate 'unmarried' is conceptually inherent in the subject 'bachelor.' Denial of such a statement would indeed be self-contradictory. This analytic nature of a priori knowledge seemed sacrosanct until Kant entered the scene with his provocative assertion that a priori knowledge could also be 'synthetic.' Here, the predicate adds something to the subject that isn't contained within it. A crucial paradigm shift, to say the least, one that allowed Kant to argue that necessary and universal knowledge about the world could extend beyond mere logical tautologies.

Kant's revolutionary insight forms around the realization that certain synthetic a priori judgments exist, and they are foundational to our understanding of both the mathematical realities and the natural world. Take, for instance, the proposition '7 + 5 = 12'. The number 12 is not in any way contained in the concepts of either 7 or 5 individually, yet we know this statement a priori—independently of experience. Here, Kant found an imperative interlocution against David Hume's formidable skepticism. Hume had contended that our knowledge of cause and effect, formerly thought to be analytic, was in truth synthetic. This was because the idea of a cause could not be logically derived from an examination of an effect; it was a relationship observed through experience.

Inspired and yet undeterred by Hume's critique, Kant set forth to reconcile this by proposing that synthetic a priori knowledge is possible, and it underpins much of what we comprehend as necessary truths about the world. Through his transcendental idealism, he sought to explain how humans could gain knowledge that seems to extend beyond mere experiential learning, but without resorting to the untenable positions of the empiricists. This led Kant to the profound question: ‘How is pure mathematics possible?’ Here, he questioned the empiricist assertion that mathematical knowledge could only be derived from induction—generalizations based on accumulated sensory experience.

Kant's conclusion fundamentally re-oriented the philosophical landscape: He argued that certain kinds of knowledge, such as those found in mathematics and geometry, are forms of synthetic a priori understanding. These areas of knowledge do not rely on sensory input but emerge from the intrinsic structures through which we engage with reality. While still a priori, these forms of knowledge extend our understanding beyond the conceptual truths found in analytic judgments. They encompass new information about the universe, facilitated by a mind’s inherent structuring capabilities – namely, space and time, which are not empirical sensations but forms of sensibility that condition our experience of the world.

In essence, Kant showed that knowledge entails active participation from the human mind actively organizing sensory input rather than passively receiving data from the world. This transcendental structure involves categories of understanding – such as causality, unity, etc. – that enable synthetic a priori judgments, providing necessary conditions for the possibility of experiencing a coherent world. Such insight into the nature of knowledge has immense implications, questioning empiricism's limits and laying groundwork for subsequent philosophical inquiry in areas as diverse as metaphysics, epistemology, and ethics.

Kant's groundbreaking realizations not only challenged the philosophical paradigms of his time but also ignited several modern philosophical movements. The profound proposition that our cognitive faculties play an active role in shaping our experience stands as a cornerstone of critical philosophy, leaving us with an enduring legacy and a vivid framework for pondering the very fabric of reality.
summary: The passage discusses Immanuel Kant's significant contributions to modern philosophy, particularly his development of 'critical' philosophy. Kant's work focused on understanding how various kinds of knowledge are possible and deducing metaphysical insights from this inquiry. He challenged the pre-existing notion that all a priori knowledge must be 'analytic' (where the predicate is inherent in the subject, making its denial self-contradictory), by demonstrating that some a priori knowledge is 'synthetic' (where the predicate is not inherent in the subject). Kant was influenced by David Hume, who had argued that knowledge of cause and effect, previously considered analytic, was actually synthetic. This revelation led Kant to conclude that synthetic a priori judgements exist, with mathematical and geometrical propositions (e.g., 7 + 5 = 12) serving as examples. Kant's philosophical question "How is pure mathematics possible?" sought to address how we can have certain knowledge of synthetic a priori propositions, challenging the empiricist view that mathematical knowledge comes from induction. The passage highlights the significance of Kant's insight into the nature of knowledge and its impact on philosophy.
